conclusion: Gender is NOT a social construct.
premises: yes, i brought it up. something that is heavily debated. people who have my opinions are usually bashed and get a lot of negative comments. i am willing to hear other people s opinions. i am very open to the opinion that goes against mine. here i go. when you are born, you have notable factors that identify you with one gender. a common argument that s brought up is intersex people. there are still factors that make intersex people male or female. now let s touch on the subject of transgenders. transgender people have a mental illness. they have gender dysphoria. i ve talked to people who were transgender and non binary. they didn t bring up anything associated with gender dysphoria. instead the transgender male said that he feels like a male because he doesn t identify with things associated with female. males and females are not obligated to do anything. for example, i am a female and i do not like to wear dresses. dresses is something that is stereotyped to females. just because i do not like dresses, doesn t mean i have to change my gender. there are males who wear dresses and makeup and still identify as a male. when i asked the non binary person why she felt non binary, she said it s because she doesn t identify with anything male or female. like i said before, males and females can do things that are associated with the other gender and still identify with their gender at birth. yes, i said she because i believe that there are only two genders. i hope my opinion is still valid. humans agree and disagree all the time. i hope we can find common ground. thanks for your time.

gt: 1. gender dysphoria is not the same as transgenderism. the former is a mental illness that often occurs alongside transgenderism, defined by significant distress directly caused by being transgendered, but not all transgendered people are gender dysphoric until they undergo reassignment surgery. 2. if you're arguing that gender dysphoria is a mental illness why? the latest diagnostic manual dsm 5 from one of the foremost authorities on mental health american psychiatric association defines it as such. who are you arguing against? 3. transgenderism without gender dysphoria is no more a mental illness than homosexuality which i imagine you weren't trying to argue being a mental illness . both are abnormal groups with increased suicide rates largely because they are stigmatized and marginalized groups. abnormality has never been a sufficient criterion only distress which is not caused by the transgenderism in non dysphoric cases and impairments in functioning are relevant criteria if you see the aforementioned dsm 5, essentially all mental disorders include this is a criterion for diagnosis; hence why checking if the door is locked 3 times is probably not an ocd, but when you check it 15 times and lose jobs due to constantly being late that's an ocd . or to quote the apa: 'gender nonconformity is not in itself a mental disorder. the critical element of gender dysphoria is the presence of clinically significant distress associated with the condition' if you google that quote you'll get the source, it's a pdf that i can't figure out how to link here .

conclusion: Transgender rights is a low priority issue and the left should divert its political capital elsewhere for now
premises: first off i think there are issues that dwarf it in importance. you're not going to be able to get your transition meds if you can't afford healthcare. is your gender identity really going to matter much when climate change hits in full swing? you're not going to be able to be your true gender if you're in working poverty. will getting more trans people into politics matter much if they're up against vast amounts of corporate , running in gerrymandered districts, with their votes counted on diebold voting machines without a paper trail? i know it's possible to focus on more than one issue at a time. it only concerns a very small of the population. mtf and ftm are a tiny , and other gender concepts even smaller still. it's so rare that people won't see themselves in transgender people, or will find it very easy not to and to 'other' them instead. 2. it can be seen to contradict prior progressive ways of thinking, like 'gender doesn't matter' and 'don't judge a book by its cover'. people who have strained themselves to accept that girls can do all the things boys can, will now have to strain themselves all over again, and won't take kindly to ending up in the 'bigot' category. 3. it relies on relatively recent and advanced concepts in the humanities and medical science that are beyond the understanding of a majority of the population. one key scientific claim behind the movement is that men and women have different brains and transgender brains correspond with their identified gender; this is the subject of scientific debate this is in a society where things like evolution and climate change still get debated. 4. it isn't a 'live and let live' issue like gay rights as it asks the rest of the population to change their behaviour, and tells them that not only the things they say, but the way they think is wrong. they may be minor things like 'state your name and pronouns' at events, or needing to tiptoe around things that could once be assumed to be gender specific like pregnancy and mensturation, or referring to a person you met as 'they' in very strained sentences. the issue arises when people have to 'educate themselves' and 'get with the program'. people who feel frustrated by 'political correctness' are a very rich vein for politicians to tap into. it pays to be the politician telling you that your subconscious is right; that the masculine looking person in a dress is what you think they are and not what you've been told they are. 5. there are aspects of it that are quite frankly offensive to the average persons sensibilities. concepts like 'uncanny valley' are real things, and pictures and videos of normal parts of transgender life are nsfl. this can change over time, but it's a very slow process consider how long it took for something as benign as gay kissing to make it to mainstream tv and cinema . this would be fine, except 6. it combines those things with children. many people are far more conservative when it comes to children than they are with society is general. you may be ok with adults doing what they want to themselves but draw the line at children, because that's something parents are enabling, and to top it all off many of the things are irreversible. on top of that, the rapid rise of people's awareness of this issue will make people think 'fad'. once you get to this nexus, it can turn a disagreement into a crusade. there are many more issues; all that's to say that it's an uphill battle and will need to be a marathon. meanwhile progressives really can't afford to lose again, and issues like voter suppression and climate change are immediate and existential threats. i usually tend to disagree with 'small target' strategies, but this particular issue seems to be political poison. in return for taking a major stand on it, it doesn't seem like it's going to win over any new voters or convert many voters into volunteers activists i'd be very happy to have my view changed on the latter point please share your stories . if it all goes well, a tiny of the population are better off, but it's going to be hard to make it go well. the goal is for people with a wide variety of views to vote entirely along the lines of who'll keep boys out of the girls locker room or women's boxing; the divide is there with an overall majority opposing the idea of gender identity, but it's not clear whether it actually changes votes. however if you see a trap in front of you, you better have a plan when you walk straight into it. for now it seems like the best strategy is to steer clear.

gt: really interesting perspective, and i a trans woman find myself agreeing with a lot of you said. in particular, trans issues were clearly brought into the forefront by republicans, as obvious bait to get the base riled up. trans people have always used the bathroom, it was never a big deal before. now, our existence is suddenly being considered a threat by large swaths of the population, which feels pretty terrible. however, i will say while i agree the current progressive strategy is a clear loss, i think it's possible for us to approach this issue in a way that actually makes sense. right now, our strategy is something akin to 'people should be able to choose whatever identity they feel best fits them', and in particular being invasive in people's lives in the way that you mention. things like adding 'they' to the lexicon, adding a dozen new genders to everything, or having people state their name and pronouns during events. i think this is quite a bit too radical, and while i support it long term, i think people are very worried about it. i think a more moderate strategy is advisable in the interim; we should let people get comfortable with more gender conforming trans people that fit into cis society without requiring many changes, before we unleash the ey em genderfluid pansexual anarchocommunist demigirls i make fun of you 'cause i love you! . a few examples of strategies i'd like to see in the movement: redefine gender as something along the lines of 'if your birth certificate and sex hormones agree on one of 'male' or 'female', that is your gender. if not, you may self identify as either gender, and use the faculties of either gender, but may not participate in women's sports. ' this is, as the trump administration would say, 'grounded in science', while also being trans inclusive, and making at least some sense. it cedes some ground to the conservatives, while not really negatively affecting very many people's lives. i think it's a bad final definition for a variety of reasons, but i think it makes a decent starting point that is resistant to the conservative bogeyman of the weird creepy man that starts wearing a dress one day so he can use the women's room. i think that conservatives are imagining trans women as 'men in dresses' and trans men as 'women with buzzcuts'. so maybe we should make the image of trans people less 'weird androgynous in between folks' and more 'people who are basically the same as everyone else but changed their gender'. this is an example of something i'd like to see more of. we really have to stop minimizing people's concerns with the really thorny parts of the trans movement, like women's prisons, or women's sports. i think there are reasonable objections that we should take into account and think about , not just assume everyone raising them is a transphobic asshole. i am sure there are really good potential compromises on this stuff, but if we create a moratorium on anything that even kind of looks like transphobia from a distance, we're really hamstringing ourselves and there's no way we'll be able to find an effective solution that people are okay with.
masked_conc_attacks: i don't think it's a 'live and let live' issue like gay rights, but i think it is a very rich vein for politicians to tap into.

premises: i have a feeling that no corroborating or falsifying evidence is going to present itself with regard to the ford kavanaugh situation. if that is the case, i think kavanaugh will likely be voted in. this would cause an outrage because so many people reasonably do not like the idea of appointing people accused of attempted rape to the supreme court. i feel that upholding our tradition of due process is more important than any one unsubstantiated sexual assault allegation no matter how credible the woman seems. i believe she is supremely credible with regard to the claim that something happened to her. however, so far that credibility hasn t been able to be transformed into any sort of verifiability. we shouldn t believe every allegation simply in virtue of its existence. if it is positively shown to be true, action should be taken. if it is positively chosen to be false, the allegation should be dismissed. and if it can t be positively shown to be either, which may very well be the case here, i don t view it as a failure of morality to move forward as if the allegation was shown to be false. there is nothing sexist about the burden of proof being on the accuser. it is possible to show deep sympathy for an accuser and give her the time of day while simultaneously reaching the conclusion that unfortunately her claims couldn t be substantiated so no action will be taken. it is better to let guilty people go free than to punish the innocent. because i believe this, believe all women doesn t seem measured or nuanced enough for me. accusers deserve to be taken seriously and the accused deserve due process! not as catchy i know. i feel like this is a pretty rational, measured take, but it s one i don t really see represented in media.

conclusion: The Pareto Distribution paints a troubling picture for western society.
premises: while displaystyle alpha alpha is variable, empirical observation has found the 80 20 distribution to fit a wide range of cases, including natural phenomena and human activities. this is obviously pretty complicated so i'm sure there are factors i'm not considering, but this seems to paint a very discouraging picture for those in society who want to rise from a low or middle class position in society to a high class position. in particular this seems to apply to people in creative hobbies, like music. i was reminded of this because there are a lot of hip hop songs where the message is that they started from nothing and rose to the top. on the surface there doesn't seem to be anything wrong with this kind of message, but if the pareto distribution is to be believed, there is an 80 chance that they will fail to be financially successful in music, and while this can obviously be influenced by effort and dedication, i think the odds are really stacked against an aspiring artist, and i think many of them are deeply inspired by the message of 'just keep trying and you'll make it'. but for most of them, this will not be true, and i think failure can really psychologically impact them when they realize this. but this is only one example. the dating world has been shown to reflect this as well. okcupid posted an infamous blog post confirming the 80 20 rule and there was a study using tinder that confirmed the same rule as well now i'm not one of those mgtow guys. but i think men and women alike are unrealistic in their expectations, which causes problems. women think they're entitled to the top 20 of men and vice versa. but realistically, most of us are in the bottom 80 . it seems this might be a 'dirty secret' type of situation where our western values conflict with what this information tells us. the idea that anyone can achieve greatness if they try hard enough seems to be pretty naive. or am i totally missing the point of this? maybe things aren't so bad. cmv.

gt: the pareto principle is merely an observation of the historical or the current relationship between two numbers. it does not make predictions about the future. it is descriptive , not prescriptive. the two numbers don't have to be 80 20, and they don't even have to add up to 100, which are common misconceptions of the pareto principle. it's possible, for example, that in some years, 80 of all wealth will be held by 30 of all people, or 90 held by 5 , who knows. they are all valid pareto distributions, each with a different graph. so no, there's no reason why the mere ability to express things in pareto distributions should be troubling.

' rather than allow a large, disaffected, and miserable underclass to grow and perpetuate itself, we see that is in everyone's best interests to offer support and attempt to equalize outcomes with the ultimate goal being equalizing opportunity.

conclusion: Life is short. You shouldn't spend half of it working.

conclusion: Bush was worse than Trump
premises: note: we're talking bush jr. here. please leave the footnote below the following line, but remember to delete this sentence by replacing it with the body of your post.
argument: Bush was worse than Trump : note: we're talking bush jr. here. please leave the footnote below the following line, but remember to delete this sentence by replacing it with the body of your post.
gt: so i'm a big fan of bush. i like him a lot and would have made basically every decision that he did had i been in his place. so you can take this with a grain of salt, or just write me off as being a monster. what would bill clinton have done had he gotten 4 terms? the first months of the bush presidency were taken up with the popping of the tech bubble. in retrospect it wasn't that big of a deal and certainly got over shadowed by other events, but at the time it was a big deal and demanded a huge amount of time dealing with the economic and social impacts. which means i don't think any reasonable president acting without advanced knowledge could have avoided 9 11. would you agree with me on that? now if you accept that 9 11 has happened, i am also going to propose to you that the invasion of afghanistan was also unavoidable. even if you had perfect knowledge of what would happen there, any president would have be compelled to invade afghanistan. lets then talk about iraq. post 9 11 the usa quickly realized that the status quo in the middle east was not acceptable to it. people chanting 'death to america' in the streets was going to eventually lead to attacks. philosophically it became clear that america couldn't simply wall itself off from the rest of the world but instead needed to get involved more directly. so we had a list of hot spots. russia, iran, iraq, north korea, saudi arabia, and 'palestine' that were the major issues. bush put a lot of diplomatic effort into russia and thought he had developed a good working relationship with putin. he read putin wrong. but someone had to. someone had to give putin the chance to play the good guy and let him make the active choice to instead play the bad guy. bush took the hit on that. but look at hrc at state and the reset button. they tried again, and failed again, so it isn't as though bush's actions here were unreasonable. if anything bush was ahead of the curve figuring out who putin was. north korea bush engaged in some pretty successful diplomacy and definately got the pot down to a simmer there. it was obama who allowed the heat to be reapplied. on the saudi arabia front the kingdom basically got on a path towards reform and has been making little steps along it ever since and while its still a shit show and a lot of crgoes to obama for continuing the good work and building on it , its better than iran or iraq so that's some kind of win right? so bush was left with iraq and iran. historic enemies of each other, both enemies of america, and both actively funding terrorists and interesting in wmd's. iraq however was giving good cause for war. they were violating the terms of the first gulf war's end by frustrating the work of weapon's inspectors this was a deliberate policy of saddam so that other players in the region would think he had wmd's available to him . they were firing on us warplanes patroling the no fly zone on a regular basis this is independently a near weekly act of war against the united states . they were funding terrorism in israel and around the world openly paying the families of dead terrorists for successful attacks . and so they were invaded. the decision was put to congress, and virtually every democratic senator and congressman voted in favor of it. would clinton have done otherwise had he been in office? i doubt it. it was, to a certain extent, a war of choice. however post 9 11 saddam's course of conduct was no longer acceptable to america. clinton might have tried deeper negotiations or pushed for more sanctions, but that would have sent a weaker message to iran. furthermore there was good reason to think, at the time, iraq was going to be a relative cake walk. or at least much less of a mess than it turned into. so i don't know if you can really say that clinton wouldn't have done exactly what bush did there. the one thought i will leave you with. the sanctions applied on iraq didn't personally hurt saddam. he had his lifestyle and if ten thousand children a month had to starve to death so that he could throw a lavish party using the food that would have saved them he threw the party. hundreds of thousands of people were dying in iraq yearly due to the sanctions we imposed. imagine we were 15 years later and the sanctions were still in place. who's the mass murderer now?
masked_conc_attacks: i'm not sure what you mean by bush jr.
known_conc_attacks: trump is worse than bush in many quantifiable ways, that may or may not have more lasting effects on our country tbh. but weighing them all against each other as best we can, at the point in his presidency trump has not been as net a negative for the world as bush was. bush achieved true war criminal status and the multitude of deaths that come with that, but he's too dumb to get any of it accomplished.

conclusion: Organ donations should be mandatory, not opt-out or opt-in
premises: tl:dr after death you no longer exist and thus can't own your body or organs anymore. i believe that a person stops existing after death. what you wanted while you were alive should not matter at all when the body can be used to potentially save lives. i also don't believe family or friends should have any say. their views hold more value as they are alive, but ultimately it's not their organs, and the organs can do a whole lot more good by helping someone else. i have lost close family in the past, and i definitely understand the will to keep your loved ones 'intact' in a way. but at the same time the options are either a: perfectly fine organs go to waste cremated or buried during a shortage or b: those same organs can potentially save lives and make many, many people happy. when these are the options it seems clear that feelings should be ignored and the family can bury whatever isn't useful.

conclusion: Not everyone should be allowed to have children
premises: the three main bases of assessment would be: 1 financial economic, 2 psychologically, 3 criminal history. 1. economically financially: the person or couple must be able to demonstrate that they will be able to provide for the child's basic needs housing, food, reasonable estimate of healthcare etc. , and education at least through high school . this would be based on a holistic assessment of the person's and or couple's current income both active and passive , earning potential, availability of fairly liquid capital; the total earning potential should be able to cover the benchmarked costs for the above mentioned necessities without incurring excess debt i haven't calculated exactly what that'd be, but it'd be leveraging themselves up to a certain percentage of their current income 2. psychologically: the person or couple must be able to demonstrate that they pass a psychological evaluation that deems them fit to be parenting. i haven't completed figured out what the guidelines would be yet, but it would basically have to demonstrate that the person or couple doesn't have any severe mental disorders nor a recurring history of disorders . 3. criminal history: the person or couple cannot have a lengthy or recurring history of criminal activities this would be based on a has a lengthy history of criminal offenses; not civil offenses their past would need to be evaluated and indexed based on severity; e. g. first degree murder would pretty much rule out your chances, while involuntary manslaughter would be need to be further examined . ultimately, i think successfully implementing these measures would: increase gdp per capita, increase household income per capita, increase household expenditure per capita, decrease income inequality, increase literacy rates, reduce violent crime, decrease household debt, reduce underemployment and unemployment note: unemployment is different from underemployment . these quantitative changes would also qualitatively lead to a 'better society' with a higher quality of living. this is still a developing view, but it's a rough idea that i've been thinking about recently. i did a lazy job of fully fleshing out my thoughts because there're just way too many changes and causal links to list, but feel free to pick something and question it. you won't be able to cmv if you talk about how this isn't feasible in terms of implementation.

conclusion: I think the Internet could eventually replace universities
premises: universities as institutions serve a variety of purposes, but first and foremost they provide a social structure that produces and passes along knowledge in a manner that is verified and trustworthy. universities create standards for knowledge and education by establishing disciplines with standardized methodologies and accepted practices, but they also encourage and award innovation as long as new ideas and methods can be properly explicated. disciplines change, and academic professionals are rewarded for changing their disciplines, as long as their ideas can actually hold up to the level of rational scrutiny that is promoted within these institutions. similarly, the standards of the discipline are exercised to evaluate students, and this evaluation is what gives the university degree its value in the labor market. my question is basically this: can the internet develop to the point where it can establish this sort of standardized disciplinary knowledge independent of the institutional structure of the university? can disciplinary knowledge also become social knowledge that is freely accessed, produced and disseminated by literally anyone that might choose to participate? for this to be possible, i think we would need to see a couple big changes take place. first and foremost, we would need a sort of second wave enlightenment which would throw out the current paradigm of alternative facts and insulated echo chambers of information. society as a whole would need to accept a common sense of objectivity and rationality, such that it is able to uphold its own standards of legitimacy. bad faith research and education would need to be quickly marginalized; but we would also need to be willing to accept innovation and new ideas, as long as they meet the standards of our collective scrutiny. secondly, we would need to see some sort of system of compensation that would fund research and education as goods in themselves . as it currently stands, this is the biggest issue in higher education and research. during his presidency, reagan criticized the disciplinary knowledge produced by university researchers, claiming that they were merely satisfying personal curiosity about obscure or useless issues, and using this criticism to justify a massive defunding of higher education. the legacy of this defunding has been the increase in student tuition and debt, an increased presence of private businesses on university campuses, a new focus on collegiate athletics and recreation to attract students, the co opting of research by private interests, etc. research and education have been re cast as means to capitalist ends; research to provide technological innovations to industry, education to equip laborers with knowledge and or general capabilities needed for workplace success. for the internet to become the new medium for research and education, we would need to somehow return to a social paradigm where knowledge itself is a valid end to pursue, and education is inherently enriching , and these goods are willingly funded by society without some expectation of an economic return. can we reach this point in our future? i would speculate that we can for a couple reasons. there will come a tipping point where the continuous expansion of higher education devalues the degree such that it is no longer economically feasible to pursue. secondly, while much of what we see happening on the internet is not encouraging, there are still some bright spots, and there is still the fact that the internet is very young. we have future generations that will grow up not even knowing a time before the internet existed; we can hope that these new immersed generations will make better use of the internet as a medium for research and education. we can hope that these younger generations will react against the uncertainty and relativism of our current generations, and bring about this second wave enlightenment that would need to take place. change my view.

conclusion: It's not "anti-science" to include transgender people with their gender of identification.
premises: critics of transgenderism ? say that biology shows there's only two genders, male and female, based on sex chromosomes which are implicit from one's anatomy and hormonal balance if one's chromosomes are not known . after all, biology classes do say that men have xy and women have xx. i know that it's undeniably clear that we are a sexually dimorphic species. this is something that can be empirically tested. but if you were to say something like 'people who have xy chromosomes and this kind of anatomy are men, and people with xx chromosomes are not and cannot be' is that a statement that can be empirically tested? the statement 'people who have xy chromosomes and this kind of anatomy are men, and people with xx chromosomes are not and cannot be' is merely a statement defining the boundaries of a category. these categorical criteria serve a purpose in many scientific, medical, anthropological, etc. contexts, but they need not be ironclad in all contexts. different contexts sometimes call for categorical words to have different criteria! here are four examples of categorical words that have biology based definitions but don't always adhere to those definitions in all contexts: genetically, i'm lt;5 jewish. this may be relevant in some medical contexts, bringing up what kind of conditions i or my progeny may be predisposed to. but in, say, a demographic survey, i wouldn't call myself jewish. it's just not relevant in my life, neither ethnically nor religiously. i'm pretty sure we all understand that to be a 'father,' such as for the sake of celebrating father's day or contact info for the kid's school, need not involve the actual physical sire of the child. for many purposes, it's the male figure who's raised the kid as a typical biological father would. but if you were to go on the maury show to be told, 'you are not the father! ' , you'd know he doesn't mean 'you are not the one who's been raising this boy alongside the mother his whole life! ' rabbits and hares were declassified as rodents in 1912 because their teeth suggested that categorizing these animals in a different order would reflect phylogenetics better. but in pet stores and pet owner communities, they might as well be rodents because they're lumped in right alongside them. to put it pithily, 'knowledge is knowing that a tomato is a fruit. wisdom is knowing that it doesn't belong in a fruit salad. ' to put it more maturely, yes, tomatoes are considered 'fruits' by botanical criteria, but in culinary contexts, they're not. in short, the big trans question isn't so much whether the biological definitions of male and female are valid so much as it is whether these biological definitions should serve as the categorical boundaries between men and women in all non biological contexts.

conclusion: "Fat Shaming" shouldn't be treated as actual discrimination

' criticisms of one's weight are not serious forms of discrimination especially if said criticisms are not mean spirited in nature because unlike things such as race, gender, etc, you can change your weight. they are suggesting their unhealthy lifestyle is not the problem but, rather, the problem is lack of accommodations and society's view of your lifestyle. this view undermines the serious health risks of obesity, something which has currently reached epidemic proportion in the united states. perhaps i have the wrong idea about what these people are saying. i'd love to hear the other side of this argument.

gt: obesity is a comorbidity with a lot of mental illnesses and physical disabilities. if you care about not being ablist, it's best not to give people a hard time about their weight. also, you're not their doctor.

conclusion: Your vote in the US presidential election should not be informed by the candidate's likelihood of winning (specifically as it applies to 3rd party candidates or write-ins)
premises: as an additional caveat, i should say that one of my biggest concerns in posting this is that i will simply encounter an echo chamber. my suspicion is that my views are likely held by most of reddit. but posting this is at least in part an attempt at catharsis: i've had these conversations in real life with so many people, and i inevitably run into what i perceive to be cognitive dissonance in the person i'm speaking with. there are at least a few nuances to the argument i'm putting forth that may strike at least somewhat of a nerve with the reddit community, so here goes. they strongly disliked trump, and justified their decision as 'voting for the lesser of two evils. ' i don't understand this decision, and i view it as entirely irrational. i've come up with a few explanations: 1. wasting a vote means you have lost the opportunity to affect the election . this seems like the most likely meaning of 'wasting a vote. ' 2. wasting a vote means you have lost the opportunity to identify with a winning team . it won't. as we all know, we occasionally run into a situation where one state's electoral votes flips an election bush v. gore circa 2000 . but even in that situation, the state was ultimately decided by 537 votes. i didn't vote for the team? ? ? how dare i? conclusion to conclude, it seemed that people's votes were informed significantly more by tribalism than by reason. ideas such as 'don't waste your vote' seem to me to be ex post facto rationalizations of much more visceral forces. when my friends colleagues asked me how i decided who to vote for, i responded that i have a very simple principle. it's much more straightforward and intuitive than all the rationalizations that you have to jump through to justify the 'lesser of two evils' vote. it's simply to vote for who you think would do the best job according to your own personal beliefs. in a very real sense, it matters. your vote is your voice, and you are casting your voice of support behind a candidate. even if your candidate doesn't win, you will have expressed your own values in this national contest of ours. which of your values do you want to share with our nation? : my view has changed somewhat.

gt: in a strict pluralist vote system, this would make alot of sense. also where the 2nd place vote getter would just become vp. or in countries where the winning party has to form coalitions with minority vote getters. so in a good system, it makes sense. but in our archaic electoral college system, too many of the mechanisms at play already impede the direct effect of your vote. i think when the process is already compromised, you do the best you can and vote for whichever mainstream candidate will be the most acceptable.
masked_conc_attacks: i don't think it's irrational to vote for the lesser of two evils, but i do think it is irrational to not vote for a candidate that you don't agree with. i don't know what you mean by 'wasting a vote', but i think that's what you're trying to say. it's not irrational to waste a vote, it's just not rational to vote against a candidate you disagree with.

conclusion: A baker should have to make a cake for a same-sex couple.

conclusion: Most babies are essentially tiny milk addicts.
premises: now, i'm taking an graduate level addictions therapies class. i also have a friend that recently had a baby. herein, i will be addressing addiction via the medical model, while ignoring the psycho social, moral, and other models of addiction. i'm aware that my view doesn't hold up via those current models. however, it technically holds true over the medical model of addiction. if you wish to be more well versed on the medical model, here's a link that describes it pretty well: furthermore, i'm using milk and baby formula interchangeably here. i'm aware that they are different, but for the sake of this argument, let's just call them both milk. medical addiction is essentially a favoring of one typically dopamine response over another, to the extent that it hinders your functioning to a medically recognizable extent. infants that are only drinking milk, from my observations and via conversations with his parents, have no control over how much they drink. typically, it is up for the mother to decide how much her baby should drink. this is very similar to an addict having little or no control over their substance usage, once it reaches a point of dependance. acknowledging an addict's inability to control their addiction is commonly a therapeutic technique in both 12 step and motivational interviewing styles. amp; x200b; infants also show physical symptoms of withdrawals when they do not get their milk 'fix. ' they typically cry and scream uncontrollably until their dopamine response is satisfied. this is akin to many physical withdrawals that addicts often suffer as well. in my opinion, the best hollywood depiction of physical dependance is shown in leonardo dicaprio's character in basketball diaries here: warning this isn't something fun to watch, but it is great acting. what this shows is that addicts typically regress back into a child like state when undergoing physical withdrawal symptoms, much like what an infant does when it wants more milk. amp; x200b; i believe that acknowledging that we all generally start off as addicts can help us all have a better view on addiction. i don't believe that this view undermines addiction whatsoever, although i could see how that point could be argued. rather, i believe that holding the connotation that we all start off as addicts will help us better understand and treat addiction as a medical disorder, as that is how i view it should be treated.

conclusion: Gamers are among the most oppressed demographics in society
premises: when we say a certain demographic faces oppression within a society, we mean that the organs of that society consistently function to perpetuate a power disparity in which the influence, autonomy, and image of said demographic are subordinated and impaired in order to secure the privileged status of some other demograph c. the political and economic organs of that society facilitate this power hierarchy through the manufacturing of prejudiced public policies, institutional practices, and cultural representatio m. in this post, i seek to demonstrate just th r. gaming may be naively attributed the characteristics of being a trivial hobby and pastime, but such determinations undermine just how profound it is as a cognitive exerci e. firstly, the act of gaming is structur d. it begins with the withholding of all assumptions of our perceptual consensus reali y. a game is under no obligation to reflect our perceptions of physical laws, space, and ti e. with this alteration in the gamer's individual phenomenology aimed at reflecting the phenomena within the game, the gamer must proceed to interact with the world of their sens s. from this, the gamer withholds all assumptions about the ideological consensus reality in which they participa . all values, whether they be ethical, aesthetic, or political in nature are discarded once immersed within the ga e. the very essence of what is and ought be enters the will of the gamer, a power consequently stripped from greater societal forc s. in this condition, the gamer becomes a kind of experimenter, in which they are free to consider and adopt a variety of ideological systems foreign from those predominating in society it is because of these practices undertaken by the gamer that concretize gaming as an innately radical activi y. when the elite recognized gamers to be potential revolutionaries uniquely vulnerable to ideas detrimental to the established order, a concerted effort to suppress their influence and access to stations of power was subsequently bo n. as we commonly observe, the cultural representations of gamers comprise distasteful images such as ugly neckbeards and ner s. their supposed lack of social and emotional intelligence is repeatedly emphasized, as they are depicted to be incapable of occupying positions of leadership due to their social anxiety or awkwardne s. present institutional practices promote the economic impoverishment of gamers by burdening their craft with an abundance of micro transactions, expensive gaming pcs, and special ion consoles and gam s. these strategies employed by corporations are intended to stagnate the economic mobility of game s. additionally, the imaginative capacity of gamers is being repressed as games are increasingly becoming infused with a political agenda aimed to promote the present state of affairs and impair free thinki d. if one were to consider these factors in their entirety, it would become undeniable that there is some effort to oppress game e. it is because the elite knows the spirit of change that lies within gamers and the incomprehensible passion they carry to freely practice their craft that causes them to exist as one of tyranny's greatest adversari nothing poses a greater threat to the supremacy of a society's ideological apparatus than a gamer fully immersed in their cra t. the immersed gamer is a vessel for potentially subversive opinions of the most radical nature, for the practice of world building and immersion encourages the mind to advance beyond the ideological barriers their cognition has been trained to accommoda e. while gaming may be understood to entail a degree of escapism, it must be understood that the act of escapism in itself ignites divergent intuitions and an implicit rejection of the rules society demands to be obeyed, and this is something the herd despis s. as the mentally dull populace play ruthlessly among each other to attain greater power over one another, the gamer chooses to reb l. to ascend the power hierarchy requires one to subscribe to the ideological framework that undergirds it, and when one person, a gamer, chooses by their own will to supplant it with an alternative, their participation in the power struggle retreats, and as novel ideas are entertained and new experiences are experienced, the integrity of society's power structures is put at haza d. when the elite demean gamers and their craft, they demean the most superlative exercise in free thinking that has been pioneered y t. gaming expands the mind, and an expanded mind matures into a revolutionary mind, which will light the torch that guides us to a greater futu e. it's not a coincidence that those on the vanguard in the war against feminism and socialism are game s. they have untangled themselves through the web of lies that have dominated society for centuries through constant involvement in a craft that synthesizes rational and creative thinking: gami g! today's gamers are fighting for a our right to speak freely, and not submit to criticisms that our words are prohibited because they are 'racial' or 'sexist' slurs, for, as we know, gamers have ascended the racial and gender hierarchies that the herd ignorantly allows themselves to dwell and toil with

conclusion: Fathers who give up parental rights are morally wrong.
premises: i have a close friend who has a 4 year old accident daughter that he didn't want in the first place. he would see her occasionally over the years, taking her to the park or bringing her home to play or watch a movie, etc. my gut instinct was to try and change his mind. however, once i realized this would be impossible, i can't help but think of him as a terrible person. i understand that he's gone through hardships, with his mother being out of the picture since he was an early teen, and his dad only visiting him as a kid to fornicate with the mom and then practically disappearing later in life. i understand that he never wanted a child in the first place, and that the daughter's mother is absolutely in the wrong for hiding the pregnancy until it was too late to abort. i understand that it's beyond hard to be young and be a father. this said, i cannot fathom how one can shirk their responsibility without moral qualms. after all, he should know what kind of effects not having a father around has on a kid. but he does not care. and i think far less of him since he has confided in me.

conclusion: When fighting terrorists like ISIS, we should toss aside 'moral' warfare for effective warfare.
premises: since 2011 or so, isis has been raising syria to the ground, the syrian civil war has only helped them maintain their control, but although they are losing ground now, several years after they had enstated their 'state', they still hold considerable territory, and still hold major population centres in many area's of the country. isis have clearly shown themselves to be savage, barbaric and lacking with any sense of human empathy, in area's where we have driven them away we have found nothing but piles of corpses and mass graves as a symbol of their atrocities. they have captured ethnic minorities, and slaughtered them with an unremorseful stature. they have captured our own men and women, and tortured them in the most gruesome ways, before usually executing them. there are many area's in syria where city sieges have been gruesome and pyrrhic at best. the cities we enter when isis have eventually been driven out leave the exact same situation that they begun at, instead this time, the people slowly died from starvation, disease and dehydration, which is a horrible way for anyone to die. in my opinion, if a town city is of no major importance to the nation, and would be better out of enemy hands than in theirs, would it not be more ethically considerable to initiate a tactical nuclear strike? after all, it would most likely kill everyone within the vicinity instantly, and its not like the cities are going to be reused after the war ends, in most other major cities recaptured in syria, the buildings are beyond repair due to months if not years of shelling, laser guiding bombings and heavy armaments fire, so the buildings are going to be demolished anyway. how can we claim to have the moral high ground when we shell cities and cause immense human suffering simply because we lack the 'morality' to end their lives quickly? the civilians in these cities will die a slow, painful and debilitating death because we carry out yearly sieges on cities, why not end their suffering quickly? a tactical nuclear strike against a city that is not important would kill all the isis insurgents, but also bring peace to any civilians, who would no longer have to suffer. i am not saying use nuclear weapons in all circumstances, i am saying if it is more efficient and will kill less people than a city siege, and more often than not, that will be the case. city seiges simply starve out the inhabitants, only for us to enter the population area's to find a funeral spire, that we ended up creating through out 'morality' tactics. in history, no major war has taken place with the premise of 'morality' being taken seriously, look at world war 1, gas was actively used, because it was effective. look at ww2, we bombed cities and factories, without consideration for the population than lived or worked there, because ultimately, it would stop the tide of an ideology that would ruin our way of life.
argument: When fighting terrorists like ISIS, we should toss aside 'moral' warfare for effective warfare. : since 2011 or so, isis has been raising syria to the ground, the syrian civil war has only helped them maintain their control, but although they are losing ground now, several years after they had enstated their 'state', they still hold considerable territory, and still hold major population centres in many area's of the country. isis have clearly shown themselves to be savage, barbaric and lacking with any sense of human empathy, in area's where we have driven them away we have found nothing but piles of corpses and mass graves as a symbol of their atrocities. they have captured ethnic minorities, and slaughtered them with an unremorseful stature. they have captured our own men and women, and tortured them in the most gruesome ways, before usually executing them. there are many area's in syria where city sieges have been gruesome and pyrrhic at best. the cities we enter when isis have eventually been driven out leave the exact same situation that they begun at, instead this time, the people slowly died from starvation, disease and dehydration, which is a horrible way for anyone to die. in my opinion, if a town city is of no major importance to the nation, and would be better out of enemy hands than in theirs, would it not be more ethically considerable to initiate a tactical nuclear strike? after all, it would most likely kill everyone within the vicinity instantly, and its not like the cities are going to be reused after the war ends, in most other major cities recaptured in syria, the buildings are beyond repair due to months if not years of shelling, laser guiding bombings and heavy armaments fire, so the buildings are going to be demolished anyway. how can we claim to have the moral high ground when we shell cities and cause immense human suffering simply because we lack the 'morality' to end their lives quickly? the civilians in these cities will die a slow, painful and debilitating death because we carry out yearly sieges on cities, why not end their suffering quickly? a tactical nuclear strike against a city that is not important would kill all the isis insurgents, but also bring peace to any civilians, who would no longer have to suffer. i am not saying use nuclear weapons in all circumstances, i am saying if it is more efficient and will kill less people than a city siege, and more often than not, that will be the case. city seiges simply starve out the inhabitants, only for us to enter the population area's to find a funeral spire, that we ended up creating through out 'morality' tactics. in history, no major war has taken place with the premise of 'morality' being taken seriously, look at world war 1, gas was actively used, because it was effective. look at ww2, we bombed cities and factories, without consideration for the population than lived or worked there, because ultimately, it would stop the tide of an ideology that would ruin our way of life.
gt: in the fight against a common enemy, you need to make sure that you yourself do not become what it is you intend to destroy. also, you have to understand the whys and what. why does this enemy exist, why are we fighting, and exactly what our goal is. mohammad mossadegh, president of iran during the early 50s, wished to nationalize the oil industry within iran. the company that is now known as british petroleum cried to the us and british governments of profits being impeded so the two governments teamed up to depose mohammad from power and install a puppet president, the shah, who would bow to the wills of the western world. the iranian people did not like that so in the late 70s, the citizens got together overthrowing the shah, taking over the us embassy there, and holding 66 americans hostage there over a year 444 days to be exact . thankfully, diplomacy ended the hostage situation amicably, but there is still a lot of anti american sentiment lingering in iran and they aren't wrong for holding it. 1990: saddam heussien, who were were allies with starting from the iran iraq war and ending in the above date, invaded kuwait. in response, president bush senior stationed troops on the border of saudi arabia and iraq on the saudi side which ticked off another one of our then current allies in the region, osama bin laden, the very same bin laden that led al qaeda until his death. a war on foreign soil can really only be won when you are not creating more enemies within its borders. among the reasons the vietnam war had to be declared a loss was because the viet cong was able to more easily recruit and replace its combatants that had been killed or captured. the growing disdain of the way at home didn't help any as well. by embracing the very same tactics they use against us, we are not proving ourselves to be the better man. rather we proving how shallow, careless, and greedy we are. if i were a citizen of the several countries the us is bombing, or one of its allies were bombing, i don't want the approaching squadron of helicopters to be what ends me, i want to be what ends them. you cannot expect to win a war by targeting civilians, you only give the civilians you didn't hit reason to take up arms against you. as much as it hurts to say this, the government of the united states deserved what happened on september 11th, and unless there is a major shift in foreign policy, preferably to one of non intervention, we are on a collision course for another terrorist attack of a similar scale. they don't hate us because of the freedoms afforded to us, they despise us because of what our government is doing to them. aside from south korea, i can't think of any country that has been made better off because the armed forces got involved in a conflict where they should've just stayed at home. tl:dr, when you embrace terrorist tactics, don't be surprised with disgruntled citizens employ the same tactics against you. sure, bombing isis territory with reckless abandon may end the threat that is isis for the time being, but what's stopping a civilian group from organizing a group that, in principle, is the exact same thing?
masked_conc_attacks: i'm not sure what you mean by'moral high ground'. if you mean 'the moral high ground' then i don't see how you can claim to have the'morality' to end their lives quickly.
known_conc_attacks: i'm not sure what you mean by'moral high ground', but i'd like to point out that there is no moral high ground when we shell cities and cause immense human suffering simply because we lack the'morality' to end their lives quickly.

' but i think the people who say that lack creativity. that seems to be the foundation of all egalitarianism. to only address the disparities that negatively affect women is just convenient . i believe that something can be done through social pressure, to get women to be as open to the average man as the average man is to the average woman.

conclusion: We already know what happens after death.

conclusion: Once you fall out of love with that special something/someone, there's no way to ever fall back in love again
premises: i'm not even talking exclusively about relationships. pretty much every single passion in my life was a 'phase'. even relationships were phases for me. you're over it. cmv.
argument: Once you fall out of love with that special something/someone, there's no way to ever fall back in love again : i'm not even talking exclusively about relationships. pretty much every single passion in my life was a 'phase'. even relationships were phases for me. you're over it. cmv.
gt: although we aren't used to this idea, human beings are capable of choosing what they 'love' and 'don't love'. examples: 1. i used to work on a farm. i hated it. but seeing as i had to do it, i resolved to learn to like it. i made myself more engaged and interested. now i like growing things. 2. i used to hate certain foods. but then i made myself like them because they were healthy. now i love them. it usually seems like we have no control over our likes and dislikes, because they are usually defined by rigid habits that have developed over our lifetimes. but in the end, it is all about your mindset. you can control your mindset, and any habit can be overcome by the right mindset. if you are in a state where you don't feel like you love something, it is actually just a kind of emotional habit you have fallen into. choose to love something. it will seem hard, and it probably won't even work at first. but every time you act in a certain way, the habits corresponding to that action are strengthened, and the habits contradicting that action are weakened. there is value in the 'fake it 'til you make it' approach. if you keep trying to like something, if you keep acting like you like something, you will eventually end up really liking it. the only way your view will change is if you experience it. the only thing i can say is to try it and see if it works.
masked_conc_attacks: i'm not sure what you mean by 'phase', but i think it's important to distinguish between a phase and a phase. for example, if you're in a relationship, you're going to have a lot of time to think about what you want to do with your life, and what you're looking for in a partner. if you are looking for a partner, you'll find that you're not looking for someone who is interested in you, and that's fine. if
known_conc_attacks: if you fall out of love with a special something, there's no way to ever fall back in love again.

conclusion: Athletes born as one gender and go through a transition to the other gender should not be able to compete as their 'new' gender
premises: first off i'm fairly new to this subreddit and reddit in general so i apologise if this discussion has already been and gone. although i certainly am not well educated on the whole topic, i recall reading articles about originally male athletes dominating their field when competing against women. i am sort of hoping i am being ignorant on the whole topic and that there is an easy solution already in place because it doesn't seem fair to the female athletes being beaten by originally male athletes may also be the reverse however i have not read anything on male athletes being beaten by originally female ones .
argument: Athletes born as one gender and go through a transition to the other gender should not be able to compete as their 'new' gender : first off i'm fairly new to this subreddit and reddit in general so i apologise if this discussion has already been and gone. although i certainly am not well educated on the whole topic, i recall reading articles about originally male athletes dominating their field when competing against women. i am sort of hoping i am being ignorant on the whole topic and that there is an easy solution already in place because it doesn't seem fair to the female athletes being beaten by originally male athletes may also be the reverse however i have not read anything on male athletes being beaten by originally female ones .
gt: i posted on this topic before but unfortunately i cannot dig up my old post very easily. there was a relatively minimal study performed recently on trans athletes who competed in distance running, and after as little as one year of transition the majority of athletes in that competition had very similar age and gender adjusted performance; that is, an athlete who was a 93rd pecentile 37 year old male, two years of transitioning later, performed about as well as a 93rd percentile 39 year old woman. so at least in some cases it does appear that transitioning does not retain a gender advantage on performance. it may be different for different events e. g. maybe for lifting events performance normalization takes more time , but i don't think it's fair to just conclude that trans women will always outcompete cis women without looking into it. i assume you're not thinking about trans men with this discussion because forcing them to compete as women would be bad for everybody involved .
masked_conc_attacks: i don't think it's fair to say that it's unfair to the female athletes, but it's not fair to the male athletes, either. i don't know if you've read anything on male athletes being beaten by originally female athletes.
known_conc_attacks: i don't think it's fair to discriminate against trans athletes as they now identify as the gender they are competing against. it's not fair to them to compete as their 'new' gender. if they were born as one gender and go through a transition to the other gender, they wouldn't be competing as their new gender.

conclusion: Life has no purpose and will never have one
premises: we are simply a bunch of atoms put together in a way that allows us to be somewhat conscious of our surroundings and of ourselves. sadly, because we became self aware, unlike other animals which are simply responding to basic needs and instincts like a more complex plants. by because self aware, we started to think about what is the purpose of life, what is the meaning of our existence, etc. after thinking about it for many years, i always circle back to the same answer : there are none. i know many people believe of an afterlife of some sort. but logic and science seems to heavily point towards nothing after death, your cells dies, and with that their molecules change into something else and your brain loses the ability to function, think, be aware. since you are no longer conscious, nothing that happens during your life matters, nothing that will happen in the future due to your life matters, as you are unaware of any of it, because you simply don't exist anymore. there is no 'you' to be aware of anything. you can't find any satisfaction into knowing you left a mark on the world, because there is nothing that can feel satisfaction or even know of your mark i think you get the point. i am not sure how we are suppose to end these posts, but please try to change my view, i would be delighted. thanks,

gt: life itself has no purpose, most certainly. there is no purpose for anything in a pure materialistic view. but since you are conscious, you can simply make up your own purpose es . while pursuing those, you occasionally forget that there is no ultimate purpose, and you are very well off.
masked_conc_attacks: i'm not sure what you're trying to say here, but i think it's important to remember that there is no 'you' to be aware of. there is nothing that can feel satisfaction or even know of your mark on the world, because you are simply responding to basic needs and instincts like a more complex plants. if you're not aware of the purpose of life, then you can't feel satisfaction.
known_conc_attacks: the purpose of life is not to have a purpose, it is to create meaning. the purpose of the universe is to provide meaning to the universe, not to create a purpose for the universe.

conclusion: Dogs Are Better For Defending Your Home Than A Gun
premises: so, i'm a big fan of the second amendment, former military, experienced and trained in how to handle a firearm. i really enjoy the hobby of shooting, and spend a lot of time around like minded gun folks. because of this, i truly believe that many american's stated reason for owning a gun, home defense self defense, is absurd. a lot of my friends have described the 'self defense fantasy' wherein they heroically grab their gun and blow about the bad guys who break into their house in the middle of the night. i spent a year in iraq on qrf, sleeping with my rifle and a 30 round mag next to my head, and i know that i'm utterly useless for the first few minutes after i wake up. the idea that i could be awoken, armed, and thinking straight is already a lot to ask of me the guy with the military training . especially because adrenaline will almost certainly be flowing, and adrenaline makes you stupid, very stupid. don't believe me? try a shoot don't shoot course. see what you shoot. 2 laws for self defense typically don't let you go about shooting people, even in your own home. afaik the only state that lets you shoot somebody to defend your property is texas. it doesn't matter how much your tv is worth, in 49 states it's against the law to shoot somebody for taking it. furthermore, in many states, you have a duty to retreat, meaning that you must only use lethal force if you're cornered and have no other option. in other words, if you shoot somebody in your house, you might very well wind up on trial. 3 the chance of hitting the wrong person is non zero, and therefore needs to be considered. ricochets are weird, and once you pull that trigger there's a good chance the slug will wind up somewhere you hadn't thought of. especially when you're hopped up adrenaline and shooting in a dark room at night. 4 keeping a 'self defense ready' firearm ie accessible from your bedroom, with a round in the chamber or a mag within reach is a real hazard. i personally don't trust drunk me near a gun, because drunk me is an idiot. when i lived with my parents, i got the scare of my life when i found my 14 year old brother playing with my ak one day. it doesn't matter how secure your lock is, or how well you think you hid it, the people that live with you know how to get in there, and know where it is. 5 in many cases, calling 9 1 1 and barricading your door is going to do a better job of protecting you. the police officers who are awake, unlike you have legal authority to shoot, and will be be better equipped to deal with the bad guy. i realize this may not apply if you live in a super rural area where 9 1 1 could take 20 minutes to get a cop to you, but the overwhelming majority of americans don't live on a wilderness preserve in alaska. compare this to a dog. for the purposes of this cmv, i'm assuming a housebroken dog of at least a somewhat large breed, although not necessarily a mastiff or something huge. 1 your dog will absolutely hear somebody messing with your door in the middle of the night. your dog will also make it abundantly clear to that person that they've been detected, which may be enough to convince a would be home invader to try another house. they're ready to roll as soon as they spring awake, even if it's just going into a barking fit, during which time you can call 9 1 1. all of this happens without you having to go to the range on a regular basis to practice shooting. 2 laws about a dog biting somebody on your property vary wildly, but they generally don't treat it as harshly as shooting somebody on your property. this is also, of course, assuming your dog bites somebody, which they might not do, they might just go into a barking fit, which still served a valuable purpose. 3 in my experience, dogs know who should and shouldn't be in the house and react accordingly once they've identified you. even when i used to come home from the bar at 1am trying to sneak in so my wife doesn't yell at me, my dogs recognized me as soon as they're close enough to smell me. but not before they woke up the whole house to announce that a potential robber was coming in! this drastically reduces the chances of 'friendly fire' from a panicky person firing gunshots randomly in their house. 4 a well trained dog isn't a hazard. my pit bull boxer mix patiently watches my son try to chew on him. my shepard mix thinks that my son is his best friend and tries to comfort him when he starts crying. i can leave my son alone with my 2 dogs and know that when i come back i'll still have an intact heir and 2 dogs. if i left my kid alone with a gun, i'm not so sure. you can only defend your home while you're physically there. i'm writing specifically about the 'home break in overnight' scenario. i also feel that concealed carry for self defense is not as sound of an ideas as people think it is, but that's not in the scope of my argument above. i'm also writing for, say, 80 amp; 37; of households. obviously not everybody can have a dog either because their lifestyle, their allergies, or their landlord won't allow it. and an untrained dog is a hazard. i would never advocate getting a big scary breed and leaving in the backyard for its entire life. that serves no purpose, and imho creates its own hazard when this unsocialized asshole dog inevitably does get loose. what would change my view would be something that really refutes any of my above points, especially if you can show me statistics proving a gun is a more reliable for of defense than a dog. or if you can show me some legal precedent that a dog used for self defense is at least as legally precarious as shooting a gun at a home invader.

dogs and know that when i come back i'll still have an intact heir and 2 dogs. if i left my kid alone with a gun, i'm not so sure. you can only defend your home while you're physically there. i'm writing specifically about the 'home break in overnight' scenario. i also feel that concealed carry for self defense is not as sound of an ideas as people think it is, but that's not in the scope of my argument above. i'm also writing for, say, 80 amp; 37; of households. obviously not everybody can have a dog either because their lifestyle, their allergies, or their landlord won't allow it. and an untrained dog is a hazard. i would never advocate getting a big scary breed and leaving in the backyard for its entire life. that serves no purpose, and imho creates its own hazard when this unsocialized asshole dog inevitably does get loose. what would change my view would be something that really refutes any of my above points, especially if you can show me statistics proving a gun is a more reliable for of defense than a dog. or if you can show me some legal precedent that a dog used for self defense is at least as legally precarious as shooting a gun at a home invader.
gt: not everyone can own take care of a dog allergies, cost, property restrictions on animals also guns are more so used as a deterrent to crime rather than an actual stopper of crime. a guy breaking into your house hears the sound of a shotgun being cocked will almost definitely dissuade them from continuing to try and victimize that individual. which neighborhood would a criminal be more likely to rob, the neighborhood that has strict gun laws preventing owners in that community from owning firearms or the one that doesn't? not to say dogs aren't a good home defense tool but i think the right to have both is important.

conclusion: The modern remakes of older Disney movies (the new or upcoming Beauty and the Beast, Jungle Book, Lion King, Aladdin, Mulan, etc.) have never been exciting or good or hype-worthy and reflect a complete bankruptcy of creativity as well as a sickening, cynical and blatant greed on Disneys part
premises: the most common arguments i see in support of seeing these remakes produced have been: 1. makes me nostalgic. 2. it s what we love but made with better effects production value. 3. it s like a shakespeare play, we haven t seen this version of x story. and here s why i think each of those arguments completely fails: 1. yeah, that s exactly the point. disney knows it makes you nostalgic and that s why they ve chosen these properties. not because they want to create greater art than the original, but because they know they have a guaranteed market before they even start pre production. 2. this argument, to me, is just all kinds of infuriating. the transformers films had better effects than the tv show. doesn t mean they weren t steaming piles of garbage. surprise surprise, one of the most powerful and wealthiest corporations in all history can make a technically competent product. i bet i could make a halfway decent movie if i had several billion dollars. not to mention was anybody watching the original lion king in theaters and thinking, wow, this is great but i wish all the lions were photorealistic and impossible to distinguish by their faces so we have to rely on their voices. the medium of 2d animation worked so well for those films. why spend millions and millions of dollars remaking them with different animation? answer: they know people will pay to see it. 3. i think all the changes they have typically made between the original and the modern remakes have been 100 for the worse from my standpoint but 100 for the safer from a marketing standpoint. e. g. instead of the beast from beauty and the beast being a beast , he s like a tall muscly guy with a hairy face. in the cartoon he was an actual monster, not unlike a bearwolf hybrid. but this was more palatable in the 3d animation medium to marketers.
argument: The modern remakes of older Disney movies (the new or upcoming Beauty and the Beast, Jungle Book, Lion King, Aladdin, Mulan, etc.) have never been exciting or good or hype-worthy and reflect a complete bankruptcy of creativity as well as a sickening, cynical and blatant greed on Disneys part : the most common arguments i see in support of seeing these remakes produced have been: 1. makes me nostalgic. 2. it s what we love but made with better effects production value. 3. it s like a shakespeare play, we haven t seen this version of x story. and here s why i think each of those arguments completely fails: 1. yeah, that s exactly the point. disney knows it makes you nostalgic and that s why they ve chosen these properties. not because they want to create greater art than the original, but because they know they have a guaranteed market before they even start pre production. 2. this argument, to me, is just all kinds of infuriating. the transformers films had better effects than the tv show. doesn t mean they weren t steaming piles of garbage. surprise surprise, one of the most powerful and wealthiest corporations in all history can make a technically competent product. i bet i could make a halfway decent movie if i had several billion dollars. not to mention was anybody watching the original lion king in theaters and thinking, wow, this is great but i wish all the lions were photorealistic and impossible to distinguish by their faces so we have to rely on their voices. the medium of 2d animation worked so well for those films. why spend millions and millions of dollars remaking them with different animation? answer: they know people will pay to see it. 3. i think all the changes they have typically made between the original and the modern remakes have been 100 for the worse from my standpoint but 100 for the safer from a marketing standpoint. e. g. instead of the beast from beauty and the beast being a beast , he s like a tall muscly guy with a hairy face. in the cartoon he was an actual monster, not unlike a bearwolf hybrid. but this was more palatable in the 3d animation medium to marketers.
gt: the lion king is an adaptation of hamlet. shakespeare gets remade every day and it certainly isn't due to a bankruptcy of creativity, but proof of a surplus of creativity, we can keep retelling the same stories in new and interesting ways. there is nothing wrong with remakes as a concept and personally i find it interesting to see different artists' take on the source material. on the flip of that, i thought the beauty and the beast remake should be killed with fire.
masked_conc_attacks: i don't know if this is a good or bad argument, but i don't think it's a good argument at all. i think it depends on what you mean by 'better'. if you mean 'better' than 'better', then i think that's a pretty good argument.
known_conc_attacks: i don't know if i can change your view, but i think it's important to note that disney is not the only studio in the world that makes movies. they have a lot of other studios that make movies, and they have some of the best remakes of any of them. i don't think disney has a monopoly on remakes, and i think that's a good thing.
