conclusion: Ethno-states should be okay and promoted
premises: whenever i see this word popping around, i see heated feud, controversy, and all sorts of names thrown at each other oho, especially if it has to do with white people and europe. i don't see the harm of every country and people maintaining their unique beautiful cultures, genetic print and general way of life. i want germany to remain 'german' in all of its forms just as much as i want japan, india, israel, niger, nepal or sweden too. there are already enough and growing multicultural societies that are the melting pot of countless cultures and i don't mind that, just as long as it's not at the expense of already existing societies and cultures. what i'm against is substituting and basically that, substituting and diluting already existing iconic cultures and acting like nothing happened. people don't realise this, but drastic changes are apparent when certain places are compared from before and now. be it egypt, iran and generally the middle east and their radical 'arabisation' or especially urban cities in europe like milan, paris, or london and their dilution. all these examples have lost their iconic charm, their soul and a big chunk of their identity. why am i supposed to accept this and act like it's a good thing? i also get that people are free to go wherever they want, and that tribes and people have been migrating, conquering everywhere from everywhere, but in the midst of that identities and cultures were formed and many very ancient and i don't see why they're not to be preserved just like any other piece of monumental art or history. before it becomes history anyway.
argument: Ethno-states should be okay and promoted : whenever i see this word popping around, i see heated feud, controversy, and all sorts of names thrown at each other oho, especially if it has to do with white people and europe. i don't see the harm of every country and people maintaining their unique beautiful cultures, genetic print and general way of life. i want germany to remain 'german' in all of its forms just as much as i want japan, india, israel, niger, nepal or sweden too. there are already enough and growing multicultural societies that are the melting pot of countless cultures and i don't mind that, just as long as it's not at the expense of already existing societies and cultures. what i'm against is substituting and basically that, substituting and diluting already existing iconic cultures and acting like nothing happened. people don't realise this, but drastic changes are apparent when certain places are compared from before and now. be it egypt, iran and generally the middle east and their radical 'arabisation' or especially urban cities in europe like milan, paris, or london and their dilution. all these examples have lost their iconic charm, their soul and a big chunk of their identity. why am i supposed to accept this and act like it's a good thing? i also get that people are free to go wherever they want, and that tribes and people have been migrating, conquering everywhere from everywhere, but in the midst of that identities and cultures were formed and many very ancient and i don't see why they're not to be preserved just like any other piece of monumental art or history. before it becomes history anyway.
gt: the problem with ethnic states fundamentally is defining the boundary, both culturally and geographically. who belongs to the ethnicity and what territory do they deserve to control? take germany. germany didn t even exist until 1871, and it was not at all obvious in advance how it would come together. what really united the prussians of koenigsburg with the swabians of w rttemberg? is schleswig german or danish? is alsace german or french? should the ethno state unite under prussian or austrian domination? what about the german speakers in suedtirol and sudetenland? or the volga germans? before ethnic nationalism, those questions weren t particularly important. with ethnic nationalism, it took multiple catastrophic wars to settle them. you mention foreigners going back to their homeland. but in many cases people were in their homelands, only for their homeland to become someone else s ethnostate. if the german ethnostate was going to use these ancient homelands to lay claim to territory von der maas bis an die memel and von der etsch bis an den belt, then the obvious solution was to expel everyone from those homelands. by the logic of the ethnostate, ethnic cleansing makes sense. the same story repeats itself for every ethnostate. france looks unified today, because they spent the last 200 years suppressing anyone who didn t fit the mold of french. the spanish attempt at an ethnostate inspired a violent ethnic revolt yugoslavia united itself under the banner of the southern slavs, until they remembered that croatians, serbians and bosniaks are completely different, even if their families had lived next door for hundreds of years. ethnostates look great if you re in the dominant group, but there really isn t any way to make one without a trail of atrocity and abuse along the way.

conclusion: Cast iron cookware fucking sucks.
premises: it is simply so heavy and unsanitary to me. so much stuff sticks to them and they seem so so dirty to me. if you scrub them, they are literally impossible to get clean if you run your finger across it, it s pretty much guaranteed to have stuff on it , and they are so high maintenance and rust prone. you have to rub oils and salts into them so they actually taste right. you have to scrape off burnt bits that are so unbelievably stuck on you can t get them off. it s disgusting, heavy, and high maintenance, with no super amazing benefits. change my view.
argument: Cast iron cookware fucking sucks. : it is simply so heavy and unsanitary to me. so much stuff sticks to them and they seem so so dirty to me. if you scrub them, they are literally impossible to get clean if you run your finger across it, it s pretty much guaranteed to have stuff on it , and they are so high maintenance and rust prone. you have to rub oils and salts into them so they actually taste right. you have to scrape off burnt bits that are so unbelievably stuck on you can t get them off. it s disgusting, heavy, and high maintenance, with no super amazing benefits. change my view.
gt: first, cast iron is far superior to others for many reasons, but to me mainly because of the very high heat retention, which is a product of the heaviness. this gives you much more uniform cooking all the way around. have you ever boiled water in a cheap pan on an electric coil stove and noticed you can see the bubbles in the ring pattern of the coils? your food will cook this unevenly too, but not so with a good cast iron because it distributes the heat better. this heat retention also helps with cooking meat. want to brown a roast? you need high sustained heat for that. the problem with other pans is that as soon as the roast touches the pan, the roast cools the pan down to too low a temperature to brown it well, while the stove struggles to keep the temperature up. but with cast iron, get that sucker smoking hot and go for it. the same applies to steaks. steaks made on aluminum suck, but they can be great on cast iron. it also helps for frying because the heat retention helps keep the oil at a constant temperature. you dunk your fries in, the oil tries to cool down, the pan has heat immediately available on all sides to keep it hot, then the stove works to reheat the pan. now as to care and expectations. don't take a brand new cast iron and try to cook an egg in it. cast iron is seasoned using carbon deposits from oils, that's the 'gunk' on it that you want to keep, and it protects it from sticking and rust. after a time, and with proper care, this seasoning only gets better and better. eventually it will form a practically non stick surface that will have your eggs sliding right off. i have a jet black pan that little can stick to. in the early days stick to frying things that don't tend to stick. in the exact opposite of teflon, the pan will only get better with each use. as for cleaning? who needs soap and scrubbing like with stainless steel? who needs to worry about harming that delicate teflon surface? with a well seasoned pan i can usually just rinse it in the sink and wipe with a paper towel. if something stuck a little, a light rub with a steel scrubbing pad takes care of it. added bonus, it makes for a great self defense weapon in a pinch. more bonus, treated right, the pan will last longer than you, your kids, and your grandkids. and more, when heated to high temperature they don't give off poisonous vapors like non stick pans do. if you way overheat them say, left a dry pan on high and you walked away for a while , the worst that happens is your burn off your seasoning and kitchen is full of regular smoke. then you re season and start over. okay, one last thing. they are the best for cooking food that goes from stove to oven. the absolute best corn bread is made by melting butter in a cast iron skillet on medium heat, pouring the batter in, waiting for it to bubble a bit, and then putting it in the oven to bake. the crust is heavenly. the same applies for pineapple upside down cake. you're missing out if you're just making that in a baking pan. no, get all that butter and brown sugar sizzling, drop in your pineapples and cherries, dump in the batter, then put it in the oven. with a properly seasoned pan the cake will fall right out. i suggest watching some videos about cast iron seasoning. it makes more sense when you can see what a good pan looks like and what it can do.

known_conc_attacks: i don't know what you're talking about, but i'm going to try to change your view. i'm not going to argue that cast iron cookware is disgusting, heavy and unsanitary, with no super amazing benefits. however, i would like to point out that i don't have a problem with the smell of cast iron cookingware. it's just that it's not as bad as you think it is.

conclusion: Parents should not tell their kids it's OK to be a failure.
premises: ok, so i already know that i'm going to get a lot of heat for this, and the kind of heat, so let me plea my case. it is my belief that each success, failure, good and bad person thing we meet experience brings us a step closer to who we truly are. that said, when we fail, go through a bad breakup, fall out with a close friend, etc. , therein lies the opportunity for growth, learning, and strength after some unavoidable pain and grief. here's my problem with that: in telling their child that it is ok to fail, which in some instances is totally fair and ok, there still lies a huge number of people who use this unconditional love as a means to blockade their inner feelings of inadequacy and mediocrity. i believe the most deep feelings of inner strength comes from within; it comes during the times you're sitting in a room, all alone with the weight of the world on your shoulders, and it being so heavy that you cease to feel anything at all. however, after this seemingly deadlocked state, something snaps and a fire bursts from within, and we become so consumed with the flame kindled from our own pain and emptiness, that we obsessively work to build a new self, and that self becomes volumes more indestructible than that which is cultivated after an extensive coddling period with mom and dad where you set off again at the suit of your leisure. this is the difference between intermittent rehab and surviving then living, and i mean being truly alive. it's in essence, the grown up version of when a little kid falls down and immediately runs to their parent's pantleg to cry and hide their face. i guess one could call it tough love, but because of the collectivist culture in america, this is the norm, because we have 'american family values. ' there is a documentary called, 'jiro dreams of sushi,' and the guy says, 'when i was in first grade, i was told 'you have no home to go back to. that's why you have to work hard. ' i knew that i was on my own. and i didn't want to have to sleep at the temple or under a bridge so i had to work just to survive. that has never left me. so am i wrong? i already expressed that it is fine under certain circumstances for individuals to go home, but in cases like a person opening a business and failing, or not being able to find a job after school, etc. , they should keep working tooth and nail instead of going back to comfort. tell me, reddit, what do you think? please think critically. if you feel offended immediately, stop for a minute to wonder if you feel that way because you have been raised to think all failure is acceptable.

' i knew that i was on my own. and i didn't want to have to sleep at the temple or under a bridge so i had to work just to survive. that has never left me. so am i wrong? i already expressed that it is fine under certain circumstances for individuals to go home, but in cases like a person opening a business and failing, or not being able to find a job after school, etc. , they should keep working tooth and nail instead of going back to comfort. tell me, reddit, what do you think? please think critically. if you feel offended immediately, stop for a minute to wonder if you feel that way because you have been raised to think all failure is acceptable.
gt: give kids the impression only success is acceptable, they won t take risks, won t try new things, or venture out of their comfort zones. great successes are built on the backs of countless failures, by those who are willing to fail, over and over, every day, learning from each failure, picking themselves up and failing again, failing bigger, failing better, until one day, they don t. instead of asking our children what they succeeded at at when they sit at the dinner table, ask them what they failed at. ask in a way that shows it s not shameful be excited to hear about the story failures make great stories . be a little bit disappointed if they didn t fail at anything, because that means they re not trying. then talk about the failure. what did they learn from it? what would they do differently? this is how you teach children success.

conclusion: Elizabeth Warren's decision to release her DNA results, and the way in which they were released, was both strategically and morally wrong
premises: there are two components to my argument. it makes it look like she is stooping to trump's level: by playing ball with trump, she has taken the bait and is now stooping to his level of ad hominem politics. it gives the right a ton of ammo for attack adds and talking points. they can now say that warren has benefited from her claim of native american heritage while being scarcely native american this fits very well into the right wing narrative that democrats are obsessed with 'identity politics' and fetishize minorities i'm not saying this is true necessarily, but warren's actions fit neatly into that narrative . the questionable morality of the entire thing will make many advocates for social justice, as well as native americans themselves, second guess whether warren would be a genuine advocate for the oppressed or whether she is merely riding this wave for political gain which will significantly reduce the votes she would otherwise get if she kept silent on the issue or released a more appropriate video. however, in the past, warren has gone even further than saying she has native american heritage she has claimed that she is native american. this is a big distinction, and to claim that you are native american when you are likely less than 1 native american, have never had tribal contact, and have never suffered any form of oppression that actual native americans suffer, comes off to me as overplaying a minority status for political gain. native americans themselves object to the use of dna tests to validate ancestry the whole idea to them is demeaning and ignores the fact that culture and shared experience are much more important than dna in terms of native american or any cultural identity. by ignoring this opinion from native americans, warren is tone deaf at best and at worst is knowingly acting against their wishes by going so public with her results. how should warren have proceeded? i believe that she could have publicized her results without coming off as offensive and culturally incompetent. she could have used the video to honestly explain that her family had hyperbolized her native american roots, that she does not identify as native american, and that she has not been oppressed in any way because of her ancestry. this has been a rambling post, but i think ya'll get my major points.
argument: Elizabeth Warren's decision to release her DNA results, and the way in which they were released, was both strategically and morally wrong : there are two components to my argument. it makes it look like she is stooping to trump's level: by playing ball with trump, she has taken the bait and is now stooping to his level of ad hominem politics. it gives the right a ton of ammo for attack adds and talking points. they can now say that warren has benefited from her claim of native american heritage while being scarcely native american this fits very well into the right wing narrative that democrats are obsessed with 'identity politics' and fetishize minorities i'm not saying this is true necessarily, but warren's actions fit neatly into that narrative . the questionable morality of the entire thing will make many advocates for social justice, as well as native americans themselves, second guess whether warren would be a genuine advocate for the oppressed or whether she is merely riding this wave for political gain which will significantly reduce the votes she would otherwise get if she kept silent on the issue or released a more appropriate video. however, in the past, warren has gone even further than saying she has native american heritage she has claimed that she is native american. this is a big distinction, and to claim that you are native american when you are likely less than 1 native american, have never had tribal contact, and have never suffered any form of oppression that actual native americans suffer, comes off to me as overplaying a minority status for political gain. native americans themselves object to the use of dna tests to validate ancestry the whole idea to them is demeaning and ignores the fact that culture and shared experience are much more important than dna in terms of native american or any cultural identity. by ignoring this opinion from native americans, warren is tone deaf at best and at worst is knowingly acting against their wishes by going so public with her results. how should warren have proceeded? i believe that she could have publicized her results without coming off as offensive and culturally incompetent. she could have used the video to honestly explain that her family had hyperbolized her native american roots, that she does not identify as native american, and that she has not been oppressed in any way because of her ancestry. this has been a rambling post, but i think ya'll get my major points.
gt: trump provoked elizabeth, and the hot head misfired.

known_conc_attacks: i don't know if i can change your view, but i'm going to take a stab at it. i don't think it's morally wrong for her to release her dna results, but it's not the same as saying she's a native american, or that she has never been oppressed in any way because of her ancestry.

conclusion: Im about to turn 18, and I am a male. I refuse to vote.
premises: this isn t some bullshit the government is corrupt type message, to get that out of the way. even if i told a few hundred thousand people to not vote either, it wouldn t have an impact because the vote difference is so large. why should i bother reading up and researching all of the values and intentions of a specific candidate and then take the time to actually go out and vote, if at the end of the day it won t matter?
argument: Im about to turn 18, and I am a male. I refuse to vote. : this isn t some bullshit the government is corrupt type message, to get that out of the way. even if i told a few hundred thousand people to not vote either, it wouldn t have an impact because the vote difference is so large. why should i bother reading up and researching all of the values and intentions of a specific candidate and then take the time to actually go out and vote, if at the end of the day it won t matter?
gt: i'm curious to know why being a male is relevant to your view. aside from that from a practical point of view in almost all elections your specific ballot will have no bearing on the outcome of the election. however, chances are you do not subscribe to that same logic when it comes to other things in life. if you litter every now and then, your neighborhood won't become noticeably more dirty. there are certainly cases where dropping garbage on the ground would require less time effort than disposing of it properly. if nobody is around to see it, why not do it? more directly to your point though if nobody voted, or only a very small percentage, that would make elections less valid i get the humor in that considering today's mess but even less valid than today. if you agree that elections need some minimal level of participation to be considered fair, then why should other people vote but not you. if voting and democracy is a trait of your society that you value, why do you feel you shouldn't have to participate? what if the vote was for the right to vote? would you vote then? even if you thought the outcome wasn't going to be a 1 vote difference?
masked_conc_attacks: i don't think it's fair to say that people who don't vote don't have a say in the outcome of the election. if you're going to vote for a candidate, you have to make sure that you're voting for the candidate that is most likely to win the election, and if you don't, you're not going to have a voice in the process.
known_conc_attacks: if you don't vote, you're not going to change the outcome of the election.

gt: rape is its own category of thing and it is very much associated with male dominance over females in a very thematic way. because of that, the fear is of being overpowered by a man specifically. the fear is tied to the power that men have over women through violence and every man is a possible rapist if they wanted to be from the woman's perspective. the woman cannot know who is and who is not. due to this plus the trauma, she will be nervous because she doesn't know which men are good and which are bad even if she understands that most men are fine. the black example is not like this, because rape and or robbery is not a thematically black thing. there is a stereotype that black people are rapists and robbers which was perpetuated by white supremacy which has no basis in fact not here to argue about socioeconomic causes of crime . this means that to make the thematic connection that one black person raped me so all black people will rape me is based on the assumption that this stereotype is correct, which is prejudiced and based on racist talking points even if not intentionally racist. sex transcends race, so being afraid of men raping you is a primal and inherently human reaction to being a victim of rape because you know that just about any man that wanted to rape you could and you know that empirically, there are rapes all the time of women by men so it isn't an unfounded fear like racist fears would be.

conclusion: The internet is hurting society more than helping it.
premises: you can go back in your past and read your old livejournal posts from 2003. you can get endlessly lost in who you were. without focusing on who you are. you can spend hours and hours looking at old youtube videos. or going back and finding people you haven't spoken to since highschool on facebook or twitter. you can spend an entire life time reliving your past. and nostalgia itself is addictive. and not being able to forget can drive a person crazy. make them very sad. you lose a parent or a relative or a friend? so you can't forget them. you lose a pet? you probably have videos somewhere of that pet. remember that band or that singer you really liked as a teen? well, they're all old and fat now. they don't look anything like what you remember them as and it's depressing to see them age. it keeps you in a perpetual state of looking back. and because we're addicted to ourselves we can't not be addicted to the internet. it isn't 'the same thing as radio, tv, movies, video games' because it is embedded in our existence. in a ghost in the shell type of future, it will probably be directly embedded in our brains. people already ignore each other for their smartphones and don't verbally speak to each other. what will a future of brain implanted computers do to us? communication will change entirely. we'll become a hivemind society. like the borg from star trek.

conclusion: Leftist and social justice rhetoric need not concern itself with "being nice"
premises: one of the bigger criticisms i hear about sjws or liberals is that the way they present their ideas are not palatable to gain more widespread support. i am going to point out why this is a faulty argument and why 'being nice' makes absolutely no difference in how these ideas are going to be perceived. it removes agency from the right this is probably the aspect of this that annoys me the most. when trump got elected, there were even liberals that were saying stuff like, 'this is what happens when you call white people racist. ' or 'if the left didn't call the right racist sexist so much, they wouldn't have voted for a racist sexist. ' people on both sides of the aisle use this argument. but this removes all agency from the right wing. it paints them as this strictly reactionary group that gleans all of their political beliefs from a direct result of leftist critique. this is an incredibly ahistorical view of what the right wing is and ignores the base that the right wing actively goes after. it's a very easy out that even when they actively participate and choose to vote in someone like trump, it's somehow the left's fault. nevermind the fact that trump is truly just your average republican minus the dogwhistling. these people were going to vote for trump anyway. the onus is not of the left to apologize for rightfully calling out the right for being racist sexist. the onus is on the right to take responsibility for who they uplifted and continue to uplift. people that get their feelings hurt from basic critique and basic vocabulary are never going to be your allies i've seen arguments online about how leftists shouldn't say 'white privilege' anymore, we should change it to 'class privilege' because white people can't stand hearing about racial injustice and always need to be the center of the conversation. i've seen men get extremely upset whenever a feminist makes a statement about 'men' in a general sense without prefacing that 'not all men' do this thing that they're describing. even though it is usually implicit. i've seen white men state that they used to care about social justice, but the criticism of white people in sjw circles turned them into white nationalists. okay, literally none of this matters. these are the same people that love ben 'facts don't care about your feelings' shapiro, but whenever they are the subject of the smallest degree of criticism, all liberals need to change their rhetoric because it made them feel bad. these people are never going to be your allies. not saying 'white privilege' isn't going to suddenly get a bunch of white people on your side. because they simply aren't actually committed enough to social justice if they let the term 'white privilege' trigger them so badly that they suddenly disagree with literally everything else social justice advocates are standing for. they would just take issue with some other thing. all this is is the right wing version of political correctness and tone policing which wouldn't be so bad if these weren't the same people that cry every time a so called 'sjw' tells them they shouldn't say 'faggot' or use the correct pronouns when speaking to transpeople. it's really just hypocrisy on their part. and just a means to silence the left. they don't care how you're saying it. they care that you're saying it. again, people that complain about these things aren't allies. i used to say 'retard' all the time. i used to say 'gay' all the time. someone told me it wasn't cool to say it. did i lash out and use it more often? no. but someone had to tell me i was wrong and i changed. i'm an ally because i heard them out and was willing to change or adapt my behavior. it didn't matter that it was inconvenient. it didn't matter that the people that told me this 'could have been nicer'. anyone that holds their support hostage from you until you engage with them in a way that they deem acceptable, is not an ally to you and will abandon your cause the second it becomes convenient for them to do so. real allies can accept criticism on an individual level but also understand that criticism of white male christian etc. institutions and power dynamics is not an attack on the individual.

gender is to masculinity femininity as temperature is to hot cold. a gender isn't 'man' or 'woman' unless you redefine these its 'girly girl' or 'macho man'. is a set of attributes, behaviors, and roles generally associated with girls and women. gt; is a set of attributes, behaviors, and roles associated with boys and men if you see the similarity in definitions, then you clearly see that gender is just a broader word for this. however, this is the sociological definition of gender, and i'm not the only one who's saying that this is what gender entails. quotes from wikipedia gt;gender is the range of characteristics pertaining to, and differentiating between, masculinity and femininity gt;gender is a term used to exemplify the attributes that a society or culture constitutes as 'masculine' or 'feminine'. although a person's sex as male or female stands as a biological fact that is identical in any culture, what that specific sex means in reference to a person's gender role as a woman or a man in society varies cross culturally according to what things are considered to be masculine or feminine gt;early gender identity research hypothesized a single bipolar dimension of masculinity femininity, with masculinity and femininity being opposites on one continuum. from unesco docs document gt;gender refers to the roles and responsibilities of men and women that are created in our families, our societies and our cultures. the concept of gender also includes the expectations held about the characteristics, aptitudes and likely behaviours of both women and men femininity and masculinity . sex is the only game in town when it comes to the words, male or female. whether its male or female or something else, and of course the mismatch of these creates dysphoria disorder. this definition, while semantically creating more than 2 genders, isn't a very useful way if dividing up sex gender. this is because this definition relegates gender as sexual characteristic. gender conclusion: "Reverse racism" doesn't exist, it's just called racism. Anyone can be racist.
premises: hi, i am an 18 year old asian american currently living in texas. as a person who has experienced racism many times before, i can attest to the fact that claiming that only white people can be racist is inherently racist in and of itself. i am pretty solid in this belief, because both common sense and logic both back up my claim. i most often hear the argument that 'it is possible to be prejudiced against white people, but not racist. ' this, however, is self contradictory because predjudice for racial reasons is the definition of racism. i don't know what can change my view on this, but i am looking forward to hearing your counter arguments!
argument: "Reverse racism" doesn't exist, it's just called racism. Anyone can be racist. : hi, i am an 18 year old asian american currently living in texas. as a person who has experienced racism many times before, i can attest to the fact that claiming that only white people can be racist is inherently racist in and of itself. i am pretty solid in this belief, because both common sense and logic both back up my claim. i most often hear the argument that 'it is possible to be prejudiced against white people, but not racist. ' this, however, is self contradictory because predjudice for racial reasons is the definition of racism. i don't know what can change my view on this, but i am looking forward to hearing your counter arguments!
gt: first, let us start with a pretty simple definition of racism: racism: treating a race as inferior to everyone else or believing your race is superior to all other races you can go check the dictionary, but they all basically boil down to this definition ' superiority' now, the whole superiority thing is important. if you think a race is 'different', but you don't think that the difference makes them better worse, then you aren't really racist. it may be a lot of other things, but it isn't automatically racist. example: i think that asians have crustier ear wax than other races this isn't racist reverse racism 'reverse racism' is really not describing traditional racism. when people are being 'reverse racist' against white people, they aren't assuming white people are dumber more violent etc. they are simply directing malice towards them based on their race. 'disliking someone because of their race' is not racism. it is bigotry. however, people don't really like using that word 'bigoted' for some reason. it is the technically correct word, but people won't use it. why do people use the term. people can absolutely be racist against white people. i know some chinese people who are racist as fuck about white people. however, this isn't what anyone is talking about when they discuss 'reverse racism'. 'reverse racism' is a buzzword to describe anti white bigotry and sentiment which exists in minority communities, frequently because of perceived racism from the white people against the minorities. many white people feel that the backlash against white people has become too severe and now this 'reverse racism' bigotry threatens to over correct and cause even more racial animosity than existed when white people were originally being super racist. it is just a word that tries to sum up a lot of political sentiment at once and wrap it in a neat little package. lots of terms like this one homophobe describes anti gay people and attempts to accuse them of secretly fearing gay people fake news a borrowed term, which was originally used to describe actual false journalism, but is now used to insult tainted or biased journalism or the appearance of bias these terms are used to quickly allow people of similar persuasions to connect and recognize one another and share the sentiment without having to share a long winded conversation. they are literally 'memes'. they are almost never as simple as you are trying to make them. if you appreciate the context and historical background of the ideas being expressed by the speakers, you will realize why they are used and why people argue against them.

conclusion: art critics are full of shit
premises: don t get me wrong, i love art. i m an artist myself. yes, obviously art can have deeper meanings, however for most art which is someone trying to copy something they see or abstract , they are reading into something that isn t there. the prime example being abstract art. you can t look at a jackson pollock splatter painting and tell how the artist was feeling, he just threw paint at the paper. and better yet, every expert will have a different opinion on his emotion, but claim theirs is factually correct. likewise, you can t pull deeper meaning from a portrait because it s just a portrait of a person.

conclusion: Artificial intelligence can't become conscious.
premises: i believe that it is not possible for a mere computer program, running on a turing equivalent machine, to ever develop consciousness. alternatively, perhaps our brains are capable of hyper computation but this is not a serious field of research because all known models of hyper computers can't exist in our universe except possibly at the edges of black holes where space time does weird things, but i think it's safe to say that humans aren't walking around with black holes in their heads . i shall consider these possibilities outside of the scope of this cmv, since ai research isn't headed in those directions. my reason for believing this was inspired by a bunch of rocks the way we design computers today is totally arbitrary and nothing like how a human brain operates. our brains are made up of a large network of neurons connected via axons and dendrites which send signals chemically through a variety of different neurotransmitters. modern computers, by contrast, are made up of a large network of transistors connected via tiny wires which send binary electrical signals. if it was possible to write a program which, if run on a computer, develops a consciousness, then this difference would imply that consciousness likely doesn't depend on the medium upon which the computations are performed. computers of the past used to be based on vacuum tubes or relays instead of transistors. it's also possible to design a computer based on fludic logic in which signals are sent as pressure waves through a fluid instead of an electrical pulse. there are even designs for a purely mechanical computer engine . the important point is that you can build a turing equivalent computer using any of these methods. the same ai software could be run on any of them, albeit probably much more slowly. if it can develop a consciousness on any one of them, it ought to be able to develop a consciousness on all of them. but why stop there? ultimately, a computer is little more than a memory store and a processor. programs are stored in memory and their instructions are fed one by one into the processor. the instructions themselves are incredibly simple load and store numbers in memory, add or subtract these numbers, jump to a different instruction based on the result that's actually about all you need. all other instructions implemented by modern processors could be written in terms of these. computer memory doesn't have to be implemented via electrical transistors. you can use dots on a sheet of paper or a bunch of rocks sitting in a vast desert. likewise, the execution of program instructions doesn't have to be automated a mathematician could calculate by hand each instruction individually and write out the result on a piece of paper. it shouldn't make a difference as far as the software is concerned. what if our mathematician, hand computing the code to our ai, wrote out all of his work a complete trace of the program's execution? let's say he never erased anything. for each instruction in the program, he'd simply write out the instruction, its result, the address of the next instruction, and the addresses values of all updates to memory or, alternatively, a copy of all memory allocated by the program that includes these updates . after running the program to completion, what if our mathematician did it all again a second time? the same program, the same initial memory values. would a consciousness be created a second time, albeit having exactly the same experiences? a negative answer to this question would be very bizarre. how could the universe possibly remember that this particular program was already run once before and thereby force all subsequent executions to not develop consciousness? what if a layman came by and copied down the mathematician's written work, but without understanding it. why should it matter whether he understands what he's writing? arguably even the mathematician didn't understand the whole program, only each instruction in isolation. would this mean there exists a sequence of symbols which, when written down, would automatically develop consciousness? what if our mathematician did not actually write out the steps of this second execution. what if he just read off all of his work from the first run and verified mentally that each instruction was processed correctly. would this mean there exists a sequence of symbols which, if even just read , would automatically develop consciousness? why should the universe care whether or not someone is actively reading these symbols? why should the number of times the program develops consciousness depend on the number of people who simply read it? to change my view, you could explain to me how a program running on a modern future turing equivalent computer could develop consciousness, but would not if run on a computationally equivalent but mechanically simpler machine. alternatively, you could make the argument that my absurd consequences don't actually follow from my premises that there's a fundamental difference between what our mathematician does and what happens in an electronic fluidic mechanical computer. you could also argue that the human brain might actually be a hypercomputer and that hyper computation is a realistic direction for ai research, thereby invalidating my argument which depends on turing equivalence. what won't change my view, however, are arguments along the lines of 'since humans are conscious, therefore it must be possible to create a consciousness by simulating a human brain'. such a thing would mean that my absurd conclusions have to be true, and it seems disingenuous to hold an absurd view simply because it's the least absurd of all others that i currently know of.
argument: Artificial intelligence can't become conscious. : i believe that it is not possible for a mere computer program, running on a turing equivalent machine, to ever develop consciousness. alternatively, perhaps our brains are capable of hyper computation but this is not a serious field of research because all known models of hyper computers can't exist in our universe except possibly at the edges of black holes where space time does weird things, but i think it's safe to say that humans aren't walking around with black holes in their heads . i shall consider these possibilities outside of the scope of this cmv, since ai research isn't headed in those directions. my reason for believing this was inspired by a bunch of rocks the way we design computers today is totally arbitrary and nothing like how a human brain operates. our brains are made up of a large network of neurons connected via axons and dendrites which send signals chemically through a variety of different neurotransmitters. modern computers, by contrast, are made up of a large network of transistors connected via tiny wires which send binary electrical signals. if it was possible to write a program which, if run on a computer, develops a consciousness, then this difference would imply that consciousness likely doesn't depend on the medium upon which the computations are performed. computers of the past used to be based on vacuum tubes or relays instead of transistors. it's also possible to design a computer based on fludic logic in which signals are sent as pressure waves through a fluid instead of an electrical pulse. there are even designs for a purely mechanical computer engine . the important point is that you can build a turing equivalent computer using any of these methods. the same ai software could be run on any of them, albeit probably much more slowly. if it can develop a consciousness on any one of them, it ought to be able to develop a consciousness on all of them. but why stop there? ultimately, a computer is little more than a memory store and a processor. programs are stored in memory and their instructions are fed one by one into the processor. the instructions themselves are incredibly simple load and store numbers in memory, add or subtract these numbers, jump to a different instruction based on the result that's actually about all you need. all other instructions implemented by modern processors could be written in terms of these. computer memory doesn't have to be implemented via electrical transistors. you can use dots on a sheet of paper or a bunch of rocks sitting in a vast desert. likewise, the execution of program instructions doesn't have to be automated a mathematician could calculate by hand each instruction individually and write out the result on a piece of paper. it shouldn't make a difference as far as the software is concerned. what if our mathematician, hand computing the code to our ai, wrote out all of his work a complete trace of the program's execution? let's say he never erased anything. for each instruction in the program, he'd simply write out the instruction, its result, the address of the next instruction, and the addresses values of all updates to memory or, alternatively, a copy of all memory allocated by the program that includes these updates . after running the program to completion, what if our mathematician did it all again a second time? the same program, the same initial memory values. would a consciousness be created a second time, albeit having exactly the same experiences? a negative answer to this question would be very bizarre. how could the universe possibly remember that this particular program was already run once before and thereby force all subsequent executions to not develop consciousness? what if a layman came by and copied down the mathematician's written work, but without understanding it. why should it matter whether he understands what he's writing? arguably even the mathematician didn't understand the whole program, only each instruction in isolation. would this mean there exists a sequence of symbols which, when written down, would automatically develop consciousness? what if our mathematician did not actually write out the steps of this second execution. what if he just read off all of his work from the first run and verified mentally that each instruction was processed correctly. would this mean there exists a sequence of symbols which, if even just read , would automatically develop consciousness? why should the universe care whether or not someone is actively reading these symbols? why should the number of times the program develops consciousness depend on the number of people who simply read it? to change my view, you could explain to me how a program running on a modern future turing equivalent computer could develop consciousness, but would not if run on a computationally equivalent but mechanically simpler machine. alternatively, you could make the argument that my absurd consequences don't actually follow from my premises that there's a fundamental difference between what our mathematician does and what happens in an electronic fluidic mechanical computer. you could also argue that the human brain might actually be a hypercomputer and that hyper computation is a realistic direction for ai research, thereby invalidating my argument which depends on turing equivalence. what won't change my view, however, are arguments along the lines of 'since humans are conscious, therefore it must be possible to create a consciousness by simulating a human brain'. such a thing would mean that my absurd conclusions have to be true, and it seems disingenuous to hold an absurd view simply because it's the least absurd of all others that i currently know of.

conclusion: Your vote in the US presidential election should not be informed by the candidate's likelihood of winning (specifically as it applies to 3rd party candidates or write-ins)
premises: as an additional caveat, i should say that one of my biggest concerns in posting this is that i will simply encounter an echo chamber. my suspicion is that my views are likely held by most of reddit. but posting this is at least in part an attempt at catharsis: i've had these conversations in real life with so many people, and i inevitably run into what i perceive to be cognitive dissonance in the person i'm speaking with. there are at least a few nuances to the argument i'm putting forth that may strike at least somewhat of a nerve with the reddit community, so here goes. they strongly disliked trump, and justified their decision as 'voting for the lesser of two evils. ' i don't understand this decision, and i view it as entirely irrational. i've come up with a few explanations: 1. wasting a vote means you have lost the opportunity to affect the election . this seems like the most likely meaning of 'wasting a vote. ' 2. wasting a vote means you have lost the opportunity to identify with a winning team . it won't. as we all know, we occasionally run into a situation where one state's electoral votes flips an election bush v. gore circa 2000 . but even in that situation, the state was ultimately decided by 537 votes. i didn't vote for the team? ? ? how dare i? conclusion to conclude, it seemed that people's votes were informed significantly more by tribalism than by reason. ideas such as 'don't waste your vote' seem to me to be ex post facto rationalizations of much more visceral forces. when my friends colleagues asked me how i decided who to vote for, i responded that i have a very simple principle. it's much more straightforward and intuitive than all the rationalizations that you have to jump through to justify the 'lesser of two evils' vote. it's simply to vote for who you think would do the best job according to your own personal beliefs. in a very real sense, it matters. your vote is your voice, and you are casting your voice of support behind a candidate. even if your candidate doesn't win, you will have expressed your own values in this national contest of ours. which of your values do you want to share with our nation? : my view has changed somewhat.

' i don't understand this decision, and i view it as entirely irrational. i've come up with a few explanations: 1. wasting a vote means you have lost the opportunity to affect the election . this seems like the most likely meaning of 'wasting a vote. ' 2. wasting a vote means you have lost the opportunity to identify with a winning team . it won't. as we all know, we occasionally run into a situation where one state's electoral votes flips an election bush v. gore circa 2000 . but even in that situation, the state was ultimately decided by 537 votes. i didn't vote for the team? ? ? how dare i? conclusion to conclude, it seemed that people's votes were informed significantly more by tribalism than by reason. ideas such as 'don't waste your vote' seem to me to be ex post facto rationalizations of much more visceral forces. when my friends colleagues asked me how i decided who to vote for, i responded that i have a very simple principle. it's much more straightforward and intuitive than all the rationalizations that you have to jump through to justify the 'lesser of two evils' vote. it's simply to vote for who you think would do the best job according to your own personal beliefs. in a very real sense, it matters. your vote is your voice, and you are casting your voice of support behind a candidate. even if your candidate doesn't win, you will have expressed your own values in this national contest of ours. which of your values do you want to share with our nation? : my view has changed somewhat.
gt: here's the deal. you are right that an individual vote doesn't pick the president. but the election does pick the president. i'm gunna use people who ran in 2016, because i've been drinking, and it'll make it easier for me to keep straight, but assume this point is broadly applicable to elections generally. now, in 2016, you had clinton, trump, johnson and stein. and everyone who isn't retarded knew it was either going to be clinton or trump as president. now, you're correct, if you voted stein or johnson, you didn't change who the president is today. but the way an election works, people who voted third party, as in all of them, arguably did change the results. its been talked about endlessly that more people voted for stein then clinton lost whisconson by. as in, if they'd voted for clinton instead of stein, clinton would have, at least, won that state. so here's the major point. you have to act like your vote is the deciding vote, while keeping in mind only one of two people have a shot of becoming president. let's say every voter had a prefered candidate who polled at one percent a day before the election. each voter thought of this person as the best president we'd ever have. but because that voter knows that person is only polling at one percent, that voter knows for a fact that this person won't become the president. further, this voter understands that the differences between the two people who have a shot are vast. if you put a gun to the average stein voters head the day before the election, and said, unless the next word out of your mouth is either clinton or trump, i'm blowing your brains out all over your fucking tofu, now who do you want to be president, most stein voters would have admitted the answer was clinton, and then they went ahead and voted for stein. so what they were doing was deciding they were above it all. they'd vote for stein, and count on the rest of the suckers to vote for hillary, and then hillary would be president and they could complain about her for four or eight years.

gt: one negative effect of voluntary voting is that candidates campaign with the goal of motivating their base over wooing moderates. we see this in the usa, where voter turnout is a huge determinant of election results for instance, democrats tend to do worse during midterms and local elections because young people vote less than old people. if everyone has to show up and cast some sort of ballot even a blank one , then riling up the base becomes less important and presumably candidates will adopt stances to attract the largest number of voters. in my view this is more in line with the democratic ideal of popular representation.

gt: i posted the following on a very similar to this about a year ago. they proposed 4 countries as opposed to your 5, but otherwise everything i'm about to say is materially the same: there are many many complexities to this, but i want to go into the weeds with just one: debt. the us government owes a lot of money to a lot of people. those debts are guaranteed by the constitution 14th amendment and are owed in us dollars. if the us splits up, somebody needs to handle all of the debt somehow. there would need to be a 'successor state' to the united states who would inherit the obligations of the erstwhile usa. for an historical example, russia was the successor state of the ussr, and inherited the soviet debt, which it finished paying off in 2006. if the us split into 4 equal ish size countries, the successor state would be left with a debt:gdp ratio of about 3. 5:1, which is way higher than any other developed country has right now and would be totally unsustainable. as such, the non successor states would need to either undertake debt payments to the successor state for decades into the future, or else would need to make enormous lump sum payments at the time of the disunion. the former transfer payment system would be a major detriment to the sovereignty of the new nations. in particular, it would mean decades of payments in a currency they no longer control to a foreign state. ask greece how fun that is. the latter would be an enormous and likely impossible burden, as they would need to all market trillions of dollars of bonds in new currencies at the same time which would be damn near impossible. i'd also add that by dividing up the fiscal power of the united states, you can end up with parts which are less than the whole. the us treasury is the single largest unified economic entity on earth right now. merely due to its massive size, it is inherently a very safe place to park your money as it has the command of more resources than anywhere else. four or 5 smaller states would not have the enormous size advantage that comes from being the usa. their currencies would fluctuate a lot more. a california anchored nation would for instance feel a much bigger burden from a second tech crash than would the current usa. that risk would mean people would demand higher yields from investments, and therefore higher interest rates on debt. markets also might not trust the smaller nation governments as much to be fiscally sound in a crisis, and you could see big debt crises like canada saw in the 1990s. this is obviously only a small slice of the complexities of actually doing something like this, but i think it's a good example of just how hard it is to actually do something like this.
masked_conc_attacks: i don't think it would be a good idea to split the country into smaller states, but i think it's a better idea to divide the states into smaller ones.
known_conc_attacks: i don't think it would be a good idea to split the united states into 5 separate countries. i think you'd have to have a lot of people in the middle east to be able to form a country.

street late at night. suddenly, a mugger appears out of nowhere and robs him at gunpoint. case b: a man is walking down a busy street. a stranger walks to him seeking for help, describing a life and death situation. on humanitarian grounds, the man follows the stranger who leads him to not so happening street only to realize that it's all a setup. he is then robbed after being held at gun point. now, it is reasonable to state that the ultimate outcome in both of the cases was the man ended up being robbed. however when considered on a profound level, the varying experiences have resulted in different psychological impacts on that person. in case a, it is streetwise to avoid a deserted road to prevent from being taken advantage of. hence, the man would have estimated the probability of getting mugged and made a conscious decision. this would then conform to his existing prejudice about travelling isolated roads at night, which he would definitely avoid in the near future. however an experience from case b would have definitely scarred him by affecting his school of thought towards humanity. it would drive him to a conclusion that it is better off to avoid helping a human or anybody for that matter to avoid the risk of a false case. the next time he sees someone asking for help, even though his conscience would provoke him to provide assistance, his previous experience would say otherwise, thus deterring him from bestowing a respectable act of humanity. on an individual level it would not make a big difference, but consider the impact it would have if hundreds of individuals were robbed in a similar manner. it would then go on to be a preconceived notion that helping somebody en route to an isolated location would have disastrous implications. now imagine the plight of a person asking for help if his case was genuine. statistics suggest that majority of rape victims knew their perpetrators at least at a hierarchical level of an acquaintance. if this keeps on increasing individuals would be wary of accomplices, thus developing trust issues. events like this would make humans lean on individualism and would make them think twice before trusting other humans. and this, as far as the functioning of society is considered, would be the worst thing to happen to it. the basic intention of law is to ensure that humans act in a civilized manner in a society. however what use would the law be if society ceased to exist.

conclusion: Paid DLC has ruined the video game industry.
premises: gone are the days where you could buy a game and know that game developers and publishers have put their heart and soul into a finished product. i know i'm being a bit naive if i said that companies like ea, nintendo and bethesda once had a passion to bring joy to their customers, those businesses in the end are still just like any other business: they're ultimate goal is to make money and nothing more. but around the late 2000s when companies started to realize that they can make lots of money just by adding extra skins and patches everything went down the toilet. money is now the driving force of how and why we consume video games. it's the reason why we have seen countless versions of call of duty or assassin's creed. this is also why the indie scene has also exploded as well, the only ones who have a passion for making fun games have realized they they can not develop their goals under the yoke of titans like microsoft or sony. time and time again we see companies take our money and leave after only a few months, we continue to be let down by game developers who make false claims. e3 drives us crazy and literally leaves some of us drooling wanting more, and yet again we are always disappointed by with product that we paid 60 100 dollars for. remember no mans sky, watch dogs 1, star wars battlefront 1? they are by no means old games if we go by their release date, but now that the industry pumps out new games every month with the incentive of only taking our money these games now seem to be dinosaurs.
argument: Paid DLC has ruined the video game industry. : gone are the days where you could buy a game and know that game developers and publishers have put their heart and soul into a finished product. i know i'm being a bit naive if i said that companies like ea, nintendo and bethesda once had a passion to bring joy to their customers, those businesses in the end are still just like any other business: they're ultimate goal is to make money and nothing more. but around the late 2000s when companies started to realize that they can make lots of money just by adding extra skins and patches everything went down the toilet. money is now the driving force of how and why we consume video games. it's the reason why we have seen countless versions of call of duty or assassin's creed. this is also why the indie scene has also exploded as well, the only ones who have a passion for making fun games have realized they they can not develop their goals under the yoke of titans like microsoft or sony. time and time again we see companies take our money and leave after only a few months, we continue to be let down by game developers who make false claims. e3 drives us crazy and literally leaves some of us drooling wanting more, and yet again we are always disappointed by with product that we paid 60 100 dollars for. remember no mans sky, watch dogs 1, star wars battlefront 1? they are by no means old games if we go by their release date, but now that the industry pumps out new games every month with the incentive of only taking our money these games now seem to be dinosaurs.
gt: why do you think the video game industry is ruined? sure some games come with paid dlc or just outright suck, but dlc is just a new tool companies use. there's always been issues with the video game industry, and there have always been companies that care about their product and people they serve. look at cd projekt red and the great stuff they produce. do they have paid dlc? yes. are their games incredible and the dlc is justified, absolutely. we get more games than ever. with modern tools it's now possible for one person or a small group to make a brilliant game. the indie scene has exploded and it's wonderful. we have games like fortnite and pokemon go taking over the public having responsible micro transaction models. do you really think the people making kingdom hearts 3 don't pour everything they have into that game making sure it's perfect? we are in the best age of video games so far. there's more variety, pricing differences, and graphics than ever before. the percent of people who play video games is on the rise. the industry will no doubt continue to grow and have crummy payment models, but the good games will always be there. this is an exciting time. vr is coming around, you can buy a full fledged system for 300 , and the internet lets us separate the bad games from the good before we buy. the industry isn't ruined it's stronger than ever. there are just some companies with crummy practices as there has always been.
masked_conc_attacks: i don't think it's fair to say that the game industry has changed in the last decade or so. it's not that the industry hasn't changed, it's just that the market has changed.
known_conc_attacks: i don't think it's ruined the video game industry, but i do think it has ruined the game industry. i think the industry has changed for the worse in the last few decades, and i think that's a good thing. i'm not saying it's the end of the industry, i'm just saying that the industry is changing for the better.

conclusion: The term mansplaining is inherently sexist.
premises: note that i am not denying any sort of institutional or societal sexism towards women that exists or has existed. at the very least it is a term based on a stereotype that may or may not apply to a particular man, though it is used regardless. i am very aware i am on the inside looking out, and do not know what it is like to be on the outside looking in. i am asking this question with the intention of hearing other perspectives so please be my guest and poke holes in what i ve said because i am looking for a greater understanding of the subject and wanted to ask in a place that i know would not be an echo chamber. a few of my thoughts summed up: 1. ken: hey did you hear about janet? she isn t talking to you anymore because you didn t say hi to her last week dan: i figured. janet is always womanciding obviously both men and women are capable of being emotional, so why call it woman ciding? i m sure you can see my point here. 2. both men and women are capable of being condescending, but a man doing it to a woman needs a specific term for it? i think if you break it down the sexism lies in the assumption that a man who is condescending is just an asshole if it s towards a man and sexist if it is towards a woman. 3. why not just use he is condescending or she is condescending because both sexes are capable of being condescending. i feel like if you make a special word for one of them you are being obvious sexist. my whole point is if we say he yelled at her we should also be saying she yelled at her. just like we should be saying she was condescending and he was condescending instead of she was condescending to her vs he was mansplaining to her 4. you don t know if the man you are speaking to is being condescending simply because he is an asshole. this is in effect creating a double standard where the belief is women can freely explain things to men but men cannot freely explain to women under risk of appearing to be a sexist. i don t care for the societal institutional argument where the claim is that sexism hurt women in the workplace and society because men had more power in those roles. i did not do that. i took no part in that and don t know anyone that has. i m sorry if someone you know was hurt by that happening but i had nothing to do with it and if you can associate me with that kind of sexism because of my gender, then you are the sexist one. i am very open to other perspectives and would love to hear what you have to say :

conclusion: Certain private companies like the social media/tech giants should be bound by similar free speech laws as the government.
premises: let me start off by saying i do not think we should tolerate intolerance, but at the same time i am against censorship. these laws exist for very valid reasons, and in some places have a few, also valid, exceptions, such as calling for violence against a person or group. this means that a restaurant for example, can expel guests who are obnoxiously sharing extreme political opinions. now here is where my issue arises. take facebook for example. a social media site with billions of users. whether you agree with it or not, many people get their news from facebook. be it through news outlets posting articles on their pages, or groups sharing them, a very large number of people get their information about a plethora of topics from facebook. due to this fact, facebook has almost unprecedented power over what people can see. what can start off as extreme opinions that call for violence, ie something very clear cut and easy to determine, can slowly erode into something more grey and harder to define like 'no bigotry'. now i know this may seem like a slippery slope argument, but i am not saying it will necessarily turn into this, but simply highlighting that it is possible, and i don't think it should be. if facebook decided to update their policy to exclude things in a more vague way this could have far reaching impacts on the social sphere. there simply aren't any other platforms besides maybe twitter that can compete with facebook in terms of reaching a large audience. if you have an opinion or something you want to share, if you are barred from the widest used social media network, you are cut off from the largest way to share that idea. another perhaps more effective example would be if google skewed search results to favour a certain narrative. if searching something neutral like 'trump' in google brought up almost exclusively negative or positive articles, that would seriously impact how information was shared. google is perhaps the biggest example because they are not only a search engine, but the premier search engine for most people globally. i am aware that this would infringe upon the company's right to do what they want with their own property, but in the circumstances i think it is a reasonable concession.

that idea. another perhaps more effective example would be if google skewed search results to favour a certain narrative. if searching something neutral like 'trump' in google brought up almost exclusively negative or positive articles, that would seriously impact how information was shared. google is perhaps the biggest example because they are not only a search engine, but the premier search engine for most people globally. i am aware that this would infringe upon the company's right to do what they want with their own property, but in the circumstances i think it is a reasonable concession.
gt: i absolutely disagree. no one is entitled to the servers, technical assistance, and high overhead required to deliver these 'platforms'. if someone violates a company's terms of service, then they have a right to kill their channel. these companies often host an individual's business model, such as a youtube channel, but so do television networks, which have always maintained their power to terminate any show at a whim. if i start a social media network with the intent of bringing people together and it begins to be used to undermine every one of my intentions, i shouldn't be forced to allow it to continue just because i'm 'big'.
masked_conc_attacks: i don't think it's a slippery slope argument, but i think you're missing the point. facebook is a social media site with billions of users. it has a lot of users, and it's not a monopoly. if you want to share your opinion, you're going to have to find a way to do so. you're not going to be able to do that if you don't like what you're seeing.
known_conc_attacks: i'm not sure what you mean by 'freedom of speech', but i think it's important to note that you're not talking about the government's ability to dictate what you say. you're talking about how the government can dictate what people can and can't say. the government has the power to censor what people say, but that's not the same thing as saying that the government cannot censor what you can and cannot say.

conclusion: Your vote in the US presidential election should not be informed by the candidate's likelihood of winning (specifically as it applies to 3rd party candidates or write-ins)
premises: as an additional caveat, i should say that one of my biggest concerns in posting this is that i will simply encounter an echo chamber. my suspicion is that my views are likely held by most of reddit. but posting this is at least in part an attempt at catharsis: i've had these conversations in real life with so many people, and i inevitably run into what i perceive to be cognitive dissonance in the person i'm speaking with. there are at least a few nuances to the argument i'm putting forth that may strike at least somewhat of a nerve with the reddit community, so here goes. they strongly disliked trump, and justified their decision as 'voting for the lesser of two evils. ' i don't understand this decision, and i view it as entirely irrational. i've come up with a few explanations: 1. wasting a vote means you have lost the opportunity to affect the election . this seems like the most likely meaning of 'wasting a vote. ' 2. wasting a vote means you have lost the opportunity to identify with a winning team . it won't. as we all know, we occasionally run into a situation where one state's electoral votes flips an election bush v. gore circa 2000 . but even in that situation, the state was ultimately decided by 537 votes. i didn't vote for the team? ? ? how dare i? conclusion to conclude, it seemed that people's votes were informed significantly more by tribalism than by reason. ideas such as 'don't waste your vote' seem to me to be ex post facto rationalizations of much more visceral forces. when my friends colleagues asked me how i decided who to vote for, i responded that i have a very simple principle. it's much more straightforward and intuitive than all the rationalizations that you have to jump through to justify the 'lesser of two evils' vote. it's simply to vote for who you think would do the best job according to your own personal beliefs. in a very real sense, it matters. your vote is your voice, and you are casting your voice of support behind a candidate. even if your candidate doesn't win, you will have expressed your own values in this national contest of ours. which of your values do you want to share with our nation? : my view has changed somewhat.

gt: this line of thinking is probably why we rarely see centrists win elections. you have to get through the gauntlet of the primaries first, which means being more insert party than the rest of the candidates. the problem is, now the vote is mostly split along party lines in the general election. say your side has two candidates in the primaries. let's say they're gop, it doesn't matter. candidate a falls about 90 on gop issues, while b is maybe 66 . you agree more with a, but b has a much better chance at getting center votes. however, you know the dems are pushing a 5 gop issue candidate, a hard left counterpart to your candidate a. you'd much rather have b than a dem, but you'd also rather have a than b. do you go for a hail mary vote, or a more certain win but compromise a little?
masked_conc_attacks: i don't think it's irrational to vote for the lesser of two evils, but i do think it is irrational to not vote for a candidate that you don't agree with. i don't know what you mean by 'wasting a vote', but i think that's what you're trying to say. it's not irrational to waste a vote, it's just not rational to vote against a candidate you disagree with.
known_conc_attacks: i'm not sure what you mean by 'waste a vote.'if you mean 'wasted a vote', then i think you're missing the point. if you're talking about 'wasting a vote,' then i don't see how you can argue that you're wasting a vote if you don't vote for the lesser of two evils.

conclusion: the US is sleepwalking into Fascism, and Trump is just the catalyst.

conclusion: humanity's ultimate goal should be to become a spacefaring civilization and we should invest more in it
premises: that's what we, and pretty much every other species, have evolved to do. there are many scenarios for humanity's extinction, most of them are based on the idea that we'll destroy earth ourselves, such as exploiting all of its resources, destroying its atmosphere or biosphere, global warming, etc. most of these scenarios can theoretically be avoided in the short term, but there's something which we can do absolutely nothing about. in a few billion years the sun will engulf earth and we'll have no other choice but to leave it, and that's assuming we'll survive long enough on earth for that to happen. so, my point is: either we leave earth or we face extinction, and if we want to eventually leave our planet we should start investing in space exploration right now since the future of our species depends on it.

gt: i would argue only one point: it's not that they do or do not matter most of the time they do not it's that you won't know if your vote mattered until after you cast it. most of the time and for most of the american public, for any federal legislator position, your vote is lost in a sea of other votes, and didn't make a discernible difference as the election was heavily skewed to one or the other candidate. you may also live in a state that is heavily leaning in one direction or another, so your agreement or disagreement is basically just background noise. but there are occasions where the election is very close, and your single vote may be among thousands or even hundreds that put someone over the top. and it's not always clear when that will be. two recent examples of such votes were brexit, in which many supporters regretted their vote saying they were 'protest votes' and that they had no expectations it would pass. and the other is hillary vs. trump, where centrists, and liberals assumed hillary had the election locked up and stayed home, whereas the right wing was out in force. states that were blue turned purple, and states that were purple turned red. so yes, votes matter every once in a while, but you'll never know which once in a while until afterwards.

gt: the holocaust didn't 'just happen'. the holocaust was a logical conclusion to a series of events, including centuries of anti semitism ingrained in europe extremely harsh reparations put upon germany after wwi the massive economic crisis of the 1930s a general fear of communism taking over the rise of a us vs them mentality and demagoguery resultin in too much power concentrating in the hands of a single very very evil manso, yeah, sure, you aren't going to just 'repeat the holocaust'. but you might vote for a demagogue using the same methods that were already used in the 30s, and you might agree to give up some of your civil liberties to protect you from 'the other', and you might demand that the enemies of your country pay heavily for anything 'wrong' they did, and you might be falling victim to one of several possible prejudices still existing in your culture. and the best way of preventing those 'might's from turning into 'will's is a strong realization that 1. this happened before2. it didn't end well.
