conclusion: The USA should bring back compulsory service
premises: all would be required to serve for some x amount of years. serving in the military should still be available as an option but other accommodations should be made for differing beliefs. if you feel alright about us foreign policy you can do x years in the military, but if you are opposed to it you could do x year serving as a policeman. if you're a pacifist you could do x years serving as an emt for some public hospital or x years in the peace corps. forcing people to serve together in this way would accomplish a couple things: 1 ensures that well trained citizenry is always nearby and ready in case of catastrophe. in a world with this type of service, if a terrorist attack were to occur: 1 4 of all people in the vicinity will be trained soldiers, 1 4 will be trained police, 1 to 2 4 will have some medical training. first responders would already be there because everybody would basically be a first responder. 2 provides young people with something to do. in my mind the service would occur in the 18 22 time frame so that it comes before college. i don't know about any of you but i was someone who went to college because that was just the thing to do. no one had gone before me and that was the route to success, so there i went. it worked for me the debt was real but i got solid job out of it but it doesn't work out for a lot of folks. not only that but asking an 18 year old to decide the institution and career that may define the rest of their lives and saddle them with a mountain of debt seems insane to me. who the fuck knows anything at 18? 3 increases national unity. soldiers peace corp should serve with others from across the country, while police emts should work in parts of the city different form where they live. doing this ensures that all americans are for at least some short time in their lives forced to reckon with their fellow countrymen. besides providing perspective this also helps foster a sense of egalitarianism since it will provide the sense that a citizenship has been 'earned. ' recognition of valid service provides a sort of floor of respectability, which is something that seems sorely lacking these days. 4 it is a project that is unachievable in the free market. while one can imagine how organizations such as the ymca given the proper incentives could establish a role in a society as a pre college and service like pillar, it comes with some tricky issues. a private institution training soldiers and policemen is a break in the government monopoly on violence which i think most people agree is necessary for a functional government . a private institution is accountable to whoever funds it, moral or no, while a public institution would at least by law be held accountable to the voters. and the idea of charging money for things that the peace corps does just seems wrong. so, cmv. tbh i've always been okay with the idea of a draft in it's most raw form but i figure this might make it more palatable for people who don't.
argument: The USA should bring back compulsory service : all would be required to serve for some x amount of years. serving in the military should still be available as an option but other accommodations should be made for differing beliefs. if you feel alright about us foreign policy you can do x years in the military, but if you are opposed to it you could do x year serving as a policeman. if you're a pacifist you could do x years serving as an emt for some public hospital or x years in the peace corps. forcing people to serve together in this way would accomplish a couple things: 1 ensures that well trained citizenry is always nearby and ready in case of catastrophe. in a world with this type of service, if a terrorist attack were to occur: 1 4 of all people in the vicinity will be trained soldiers, 1 4 will be trained police, 1 to 2 4 will have some medical training. first responders would already be there because everybody would basically be a first responder. 2 provides young people with something to do. in my mind the service would occur in the 18 22 time frame so that it comes before college. i don't know about any of you but i was someone who went to college because that was just the thing to do. no one had gone before me and that was the route to success, so there i went. it worked for me the debt was real but i got solid job out of it but it doesn't work out for a lot of folks. not only that but asking an 18 year old to decide the institution and career that may define the rest of their lives and saddle them with a mountain of debt seems insane to me. who the fuck knows anything at 18? 3 increases national unity. soldiers peace corp should serve with others from across the country, while police emts should work in parts of the city different form where they live. doing this ensures that all americans are for at least some short time in their lives forced to reckon with their fellow countrymen. besides providing perspective this also helps foster a sense of egalitarianism since it will provide the sense that a citizenship has been 'earned. ' recognition of valid service provides a sort of floor of respectability, which is something that seems sorely lacking these days. 4 it is a project that is unachievable in the free market. while one can imagine how organizations such as the ymca given the proper incentives could establish a role in a society as a pre college and service like pillar, it comes with some tricky issues. a private institution training soldiers and policemen is a break in the government monopoly on violence which i think most people agree is necessary for a functional government . a private institution is accountable to whoever funds it, moral or no, while a public institution would at least by law be held accountable to the voters. and the idea of charging money for things that the peace corps does just seems wrong. so, cmv. tbh i've always been okay with the idea of a draft in it's most raw form but i figure this might make it more palatable for people who don't.
gt: alright first i'm gonna go through your points and then i'd like to talk about my own1. you are assuming that this x years of service and or training is going to stick with people. just because you make someone serve at a hospital does not mean they will remember cpr for their whole life which is why that certification requires frequent update. i learned spanish for 3 years in highschool and don't remember a damn thing. especially if people aren't interested in it because they are being made to do it, they probably won't retain a lot of that training for very long2. yes. but some young people have something to do. there are a number of you get engineers and doctors that do know that's what they want and are ready to go through engineering or medical school. it might not be the best move to go to college if it's going to cause you debt, but in some fields, particularly engineering, the somewhat gaurantee of a job after college is enough to offset this. when i was 18 i wanted to be a chemical engineer. after 2 years if engineering school i decided i would wrong, and i wanted to be a software engineer. i wouldn't have been able to make that decision serving in any of the fields you mentioned3. it sounds like you're going to force a lot of people away from home. for me, i wouldn't mind, but a lot of people will be really rattled by this. just a thought. i do agree that meeting diverse people is positive though4. i agree, however these programs thrive despite not having a service requirementhere are my main issues with this1. a free country try should never force service on it's citizens. in a country that was founded upon personal freedoms, one of those freedoms is to disagree with the country itself. forcing someone to serve is very authoritarian, and not charactaistic of a country like the us. personally i think the draft is absolutely horse shit. i would never serve in the military and i wouldn't work in any branch of government for that matter and that is my right as a us citizen. 2. we don't need to draft people into these fields. there is no shortage of military. we have the largest military in the world by far and it is all volunteer as far as i know . perhaps the other fields could benefit from more people but as far as i know, we are still fine in those areas too. 3. i don't like the concept of being required to serve your country. maybe this is a personal thing. but you didn't ask to be born here and for most people there's nothing you can do about it. requiring someone to do service without their consent, to me, is a human rights violation. and i know some countries do this, and i oppose that greatly
masked_conc_attacks: i'm not sure what you're trying to accomplish here, but i'm going to try to change your view. i'm a pacifist, and i don't want to be forced to serve in the military. i want to live in a country where there is no need for me to be a police officer. i'd rather live in an area where there are no police officers than in a place where there's no need to be an emt.
known_conc_attacks: i'm not sure what you mean by compulsory service, but i think it would be a good idea to make it mandatory for all citizens to serve in the military. i don't think it's a great idea to force people to do something they don't want to do, but it's not a bad idea.

conclusion: The N-word is overly stigmatized and should be used freely in certain settings (such as academics)
premises: i'll preface this by saying: for those of you that don't know, the n word refers to 'nigger'. i'll simply refer to the term by 'nword' from here on out to avoid offending people. and although i may share this view on other euphemisms, i'll strictly be discussing the nword to keep the conversation scope narrow. when discussing the root origins of the word, people fear speaking it out loud. even i cringed when i typed out the nword in my first paragraph. stigmatizing the word gives it more power. that's like saying, 'hey! don't remind black people that they were once oppressed slaves! keep it on the hush hush. ' i believe the attitude should instead be more along the lines of, 'blacks should be proud of how empowered they've become despite societal oppression. so keep using it. we don't care because it only shows the leaps and bounds they've made in recent decades. ' we don't use 'the c word' for chink or 'the c word' for cracker. in fact, especially stigmatizing the nword over other racial slurs seems to send a message that other racial slurs are more ok when they should all be equally frowned upon in colloquial language.
argument: The N-word is overly stigmatized and should be used freely in certain settings (such as academics) : i'll preface this by saying: for those of you that don't know, the n word refers to 'nigger'. i'll simply refer to the term by 'nword' from here on out to avoid offending people. and although i may share this view on other euphemisms, i'll strictly be discussing the nword to keep the conversation scope narrow. when discussing the root origins of the word, people fear speaking it out loud. even i cringed when i typed out the nword in my first paragraph. stigmatizing the word gives it more power. that's like saying, 'hey! don't remind black people that they were once oppressed slaves! keep it on the hush hush. ' i believe the attitude should instead be more along the lines of, 'blacks should be proud of how empowered they've become despite societal oppression. so keep using it. we don't care because it only shows the leaps and bounds they've made in recent decades. ' we don't use 'the c word' for chink or 'the c word' for cracker. in fact, especially stigmatizing the nword over other racial slurs seems to send a message that other racial slurs are more ok when they should all be equally frowned upon in colloquial language.
gt: if you feel it 'should' be used freely in some cases, why do you self censor all but one time here? if you think it is the best option to self censor to avoid offending , why accuse everyone else of being wrong when they make the same decision you do?
masked_conc_attacks: i don't think stigmatizing the n word gives it more power. i think it's important to remember that the word is used to refer to a group of people, not a single group. it's not a slur, it's a word used to describe a group.
known_conc_attacks: i don't think it's stigmatized, but i do think it should be used freely in certain settings. for example, in the us, the word 'nigger' is used as a derogatory term for black people. it's used to refer to black people, but it's also used as an insult to white people.

conclusion: Rape and domestic violence carried out by female perpetrators will never be taken seriously by society
premises: am i an advocate for both of these things? god no. maybe they'd be mocked or slandered, who knows. south park did a very good episode highlighting this topic if anyone has seen it. i've had this opinion for a while now but decided to make this post after hearing about a video regarding it on the front page yesterday.
argument: Rape and domestic violence carried out by female perpetrators will never be taken seriously by society : am i an advocate for both of these things? god no. maybe they'd be mocked or slandered, who knows. south park did a very good episode highlighting this topic if anyone has seen it. i've had this opinion for a while now but decided to make this post after hearing about a video regarding it on the front page yesterday.
gt: i'm not really sure why you think you can say that it will never be taken seriously by 'society', unless you just mean in sitcoms or something. an ever increasing number of women are convicted of domestic violence will it be taken as seriously as domestic violence by men? probably not, because men are statistically stronger than women, and serious injuries and death among male victims are far lower than the reverse. but that doesn't mean that it's not taken seriously when it happens. will there be jokes about female perpetrators and or their male victims? sure. but surely you've encountered jokes about male perpetrators and female victims, have you not? what do you call a woman with 2 black eyes? a slow learner. i mean i really don't see a lot of evidence, for example, that lorena bobbit wasn't treated seriously by the legal system for cutting off her husband's penis, do you? the fact that there are jokes about the victim in this case doesn't change how seriously 'society', in the form of our elected government, took it.
masked_conc_attacks: i don't think south park should be mocked or slandered. i think they should be praised for their work.
known_conc_attacks: i don't think it's fair to say that women will never be taken seriously in society. i think that's because they are victims of rape and domestic violence. if you're a victim of rape or domestic violence, it's not fair to assume that you're the victim of a crime committed by a woman. i'm not saying that you should be fearful for them should society find out, i'm saying that it's unfair to expect them to be held accountable for their actions.

conclusion: It is unethical to expose your child to video games.
premises: when parents purchase their children playstations, x box's, gaming pcs, etc, i see this is a serious moral failing. i hold this view because of the following intuitions: it decreases the child's attentiveness to school work. it can increase their propensity for violence. it can lead to the development of addictive personality. it decreases the possibility of the child focussing on other more worthwhile pursuits, such as human reading, going outside, learning, etc.
argument: It is unethical to expose your child to video games. : when parents purchase their children playstations, x box's, gaming pcs, etc, i see this is a serious moral failing. i hold this view because of the following intuitions: it decreases the child's attentiveness to school work. it can increase their propensity for violence. it can lead to the development of addictive personality. it decreases the possibility of the child focussing on other more worthwhile pursuits, such as human reading, going outside, learning, etc.
gt: have you played any video games recently? i ask because while there is certainly no shortage of games that include violence and lots of action, there are also a great many which do not, and in fact are about things like spirituality, exploration, and what it means to be human. they are thought provoking and morally enriching. to get a sense of what i'm talking about, check out a game called journey. here is a link to a full play through with no commentary about the length of a short film :
masked_conc_attacks: i don't think it's a moral failing to buy a playstation, but i do think it is a moral failure to purchase a gaming pc.
known_conc_attacks: i don't think it's unethical to expose your child to video games, but i do think it is unethical for parents to expose their children to violent video games.
